chunk_title: Requirements for an Operational Risk Assessment
chunk_text:
The information sets out the mandatory elements that an operational risk assessment must address for an unmanned aircraft system operation. First, the assessment must describe the characteristics of the UAS operation, establishing what is intended to be flown, how it will be conducted, and under which conditions seen in the concept of operations.

The assessment must then propose adequate operational safety objectives that are appropriate to the nature and risk of the operation. These objectives define the safety outcomes that must be achieved to ensure the operation can be conducted safely.

A key requirement is the identification of risks both on the ground and in the air. This risk identification must consider several specific aspects. These include the extent to which third parties or property on the ground could be endangered by the activity, as well as the complexity, performance, and operational characteristics of the unmanned aircraft involved. The assessment must also consider the purpose of the flight, the type of UAS, the probability of collision with other aircraft, and the class of airspace used. In addition, the type, scale, and complexity of the UAS operation or activity must be taken into account, including, where relevant, the size and type of traffic handled by the responsible organisation or person. Finally, the assessment must consider the extent to which persons affected by the risks involved in the UAS operation are able to assess and exercise control over those risks.

Beyond identifying risks, the operational risk assessment must identify a range of possible risk mitigating measures. From these measures, the assessment must determine the necessary level of robustness required for the selected mitigations, ensuring that the overall operation can be conducted safely.
chunk_summary: The requirements define a structured approach to operational risk assessment for UAS operations. They require a clear description of the operation, identification of ground and air risks, consideration of multiple operational and contextual factors, and the selection of mitigations with an appropriate level of robustness. The ultimate goal is to demonstrate that the operation can be conducted safely.

chunk_title: Required Content of the Description of a UAS Operation
chunk_text:
The information specifies the minimum elements that must be included when describing a unmanned aircraft system operation as part of an operational risk assessment. The description must first address the nature of the activities performed, clearly explaining what the operation consists of and what tasks or services are being carried out.

It must then describe the operational environment and the geographical area in which the intended operation will take place. This includes details of the population that will be overflown, the orography of the area, the types of airspace involved, and the airspace volume in which the operation will occur. The description must also identify which airspace volume is kept as necessary risk buffers and include any operational requirements related to geographical zones.

The complexity of the operation must be described, with particular attention to how the operation is planned and executed. This includes the personnel competencies required, their experience and composition, and the technical means that are planned to conduct the operation.

The description must also cover the technical features of the UAS. This includes the performance of the unmanned aircraft in relation to the conditions of the planned operation and, where applicable, the registration number of the UAS.

Finally, the description must address the competence of the personnel conducting the operation. This includes the composition of the personnel, their roles and responsibilities, their training, and their recent experience relevant to the operation.
chunk_summary: The requirements define the minimum information needed to clearly describe a UAS operation. They cover the activity itself, the operating environment, operational complexity, technical characteristics of the UAS, and the competence of the personnel involved. Together, these elements provide a comprehensive basis for understanding the operation and assessing its associated risks.

chunk_title: Target Level of Safety Equivalent to Manned Aviation for UAS Operations
chunk_text: The assessment shall propose a target level of safety. That target level of safety shall be equivalent to the safety level in manned aviation, taking into account the specific characteristics of the UAS operation.
chunk_summary: A target level of safety must be proposed as part of the assessment. This target must match the safety level achieved in manned aviation while reflecting the specific characteristics of the UAS operation.

chunk_title: Determination of Unmitigated Ground and Air Risks in an Operational Risk Assessment
chunk_text:
This content specifies the elements that must be determined when identifying the risks associated with an operation. The identification of risks explicitly includes both unmitigated ground risk and unmitigated air risk, each assessed according to defined criteria.

The unmitigated ground risk of the operation is determined by considering the type of operation and the conditions under which the operation takes place. This determination includes whether the operation is conducted under visual line of sight or beyond visual line of sight, the population density of the areas being overflown, whether the operation involves flying over an assembly of people, and the dimension characteristics of the unmanned aircraft.

The unmitigated air risk of the operation is determined by considering the characteristics of the airspace and the interaction with other air traffic. This includes defining the exact airspace volume where the operation will take place, extended by any additional airspace volume required for contingency procedures. The class of airspace is taken into account, along with the impact on other air traffic and air traffic management. This impact assessment specifically considers the altitude of the operation, whether the airspace is controlled or uncontrolled, whether the operation takes place in an aerodrome or non-aerodrome environment, whether the airspace is over an urban or rural environment, and the level of separation from other traffic.
chunk_summary: The risk identification process requires a structured determination of both ground and air risks before mitigations are applied. Ground risk focuses on operational mode, population exposure, and aircraft size, while air risk focuses on airspace characteristics and interactions with other traffic. Together, these elements form the basis for assessing the inherent risks of the operation.

chunk_title: Identification of Mitigation Measures to Meet the Target Level of Safety
chunk_text:
The information defines the range of mitigation measures that must be considered when identifying how a proposed unmanned aircraft system operation will meet the target level of safety. These mitigation measures address risks on the ground and in the air and span operational, organisational, human, and technical aspects of the operation.

The assessment must consider containment measures for people on the ground, which are intended to limit the exposure of third parties to potential hazards arising from the operation. In addition, strategic operational limitations must be considered. These include restricting the geographical volumes in which the operation takes place and restricting the duration or scheduling of the time slots during which the operation is conducted.

Strategic mitigation may also be achieved through the application of common flight rules or the use of common airspace structures and services. The ability of the operation to cope with possible adverse operating conditions must be considered as well, ensuring that safety is maintained when environmental or operational conditions deteriorate.

Organisational factors form another category of mitigation measures. These include operational and maintenance procedures developed by the UAS operator, as well as maintenance procedures that comply with the manufacturer’s user manual. The level of competency and expertise of the personnel involved in ensuring flight safety must also be taken into account, together with the risk of human error in the application of operational procedures.

Finally, the identification of mitigation measures must consider the design features and performance of the UAS. This includes the availability of means to mitigate the risk of collision, the availability of systems that limit the energy at impact or enhance the frangibility of the unmanned aircraft, and the design of the UAS in accordance with recognised standards, including fail-safe design principles.
chunk_summary: The requirements outline a comprehensive set of mitigation options that must be considered to achieve the target level of safety for a UAS operation. These options cover containment, operational limitations, strategic airspace measures, organisational and human factors, and technical design features of the UAS. Together, they ensure that risks are addressed through multiple complementary layers of mitigation.

chunk_title: Assessment of Robustness of Proposed Mitigating Measures
chunk_text:
The information states that the robustness of the proposed mitigating measures must be assessed. This assessment is performed to determine whether the mitigating measures are commensurate with both the safety objectives and the risks associated with the intended operation.

A specific emphasis is placed on ensuring that the relationship between mitigations, safety objectives, and operational risks is appropriate throughout the operation. The purpose is to make sure that every stage of the operation is safe, meaning the mitigations must provide sufficient strength and reliability relative to the hazards that may arise during planning, execution, and any other phases of the intended operation.
chunk_summary: The statement requires an evaluation of how robust the selected mitigations are relative to the operation’s risks and safety objectives. This check is intended to confirm the mitigations are suitably matched to the hazards. It also stresses that safety must be ensured at every stage of the operation.

chunk_title: GM1 AMC1 Article 11 Rules for conducting an operational risk assessment
chunk_text:
The information explains how the operational risk assessment required by Article 11 of the UAS Regulation may be conducted and which methodologies and alternatives are acceptable. The operational risk assessment may be carried out using the methodology described in AMC1 Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. This methodology is essentially the specific operations risk assessment, known as SORA, which was developed by JARUS. While SORA is presented as an acceptable means of compliance, other methodologies may also be used by the UAS operator as alternative means of compliance, provided they satisfy the regulatory requirements.

It is clarified that unmanned free balloons are considered unmanned aircraft and must therefore comply with Regulation (EU) 2019/947. For this specific type of aircraft, compliance with Appendix 2 to Regulation (EU) No 923/2012 is regarded as an acceptable means of compliance with Article 11.

The text further explains that aspects other than safety, including security, privacy, environmental protection, and the use of the radio frequency spectrum, should be assessed separately. These aspects must be addressed in accordance with the applicable requirements established by the Member State in which the operation is intended to take place, or in accordance with other relevant EU regulations.

For certain UAS operations that fall within the ‘specific’ category, alternatives to conducting a full risk assessment are available. For UAS operations with lower intrinsic risks, a declaration may be submitted when the operation complies with the standard scenarios listed in Appendix 1 to the UAS Regulation. A summary of these standard scenarios is provided in Table 1. For other UAS operations, a request for authorisation may be submitted based on the mitigations and provisions described in a predefined risk assessment, provided that the UAS operation meets the operational characterisation described in AMC2 and subsequent provisions to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. A summary of the predefined risk assessments that have been published so far is provided in Table 2.

The text notes that while standard scenarios are described in a detailed and prescriptive manner, the provisions and mitigations contained in predefined risk assessments are described in a more generic way. This approach is intended to provide flexibility to UAS operators and competent authorities, allowing them to establish more prescriptive limitations and provisions that are adapted to the specific characteristics of the intended operation. Two types of predefined risk assessments are identified. One type consists of PDRAs derived from a standard scenario, which allow the UAS operator to conduct similar operations but using, for example, UAS without the class label required by the standard scenario, such as privately built UAS. The second type consists of more generic PDRAs.

The codification of a predefined risk assessment includes the letter ‘G’ or ‘S’, such as PDRA-G01 or PDRA-S01. The letter ‘G’ designates generic PDRAs. The letter ‘S’ designates PDRAs that are derived from a standard scenario and have the same level of prescriptiveness as the corresponding standard scenario. These PDRAs, although they apply to UAS operations that require operational authorisation in order to allow the use of UAS without a class label, are expected to enable an even more simplified authorisation process compared to other PDRAs that are not related to standard scenarios. Ideally, for operations conducted on the basis of such PDRAs, competent authorities may implement expedited operational authorisation processes. These processes may be based on a review of the documentation submitted by the UAS operator to support the declaration of compliance with the PDRA provisions.

In accordance with Article 11 of the UAS Regulation, the applicant is required to collect and provide the relevant technical, operational, and system information needed to assess the risk associated with the intended UAS operation. The SORA methodology described in AMC1 Article 11 provides a detailed framework for this data collection and presentation. The concept of operations, or ConOps, description forms the foundation for all other activities and should be as accurate and detailed as possible. The ConOps should not only describe the operation itself but also provide insight into the UAS operator’s operational safety culture. It should further include information on how and when interaction with the air navigation service provider is expected, where applicable.

It is also specified that predefined risk assessments address only safety risks. As a result, additional limitations and provisions may need to be included after considering other types of risks, such as security or privacy risks.

When a UAS operator intends to conduct an operation covered by a predefined risk assessment, the operator should complete the last two columns of the table related to the selected PDRA, titled ‘integrity’ and ‘proof’. In the integrity column, the operator explains how the required level of integrity is met, and in the proof column, how that level of integrity is demonstrated. To support UAS operators, these two columns are already prefilled, although operators may adapt the text to suit their specific needs.

If a UAS operation does not fully fit within the limits defined by a predefined risk assessment, the UAS operator is required to carry out a full risk assessment and submit it to the competent authority. Changes to a predefined risk assessment should not be made unless the competent authority accepts that minor changes may be introduced.

For the purposes of the SORA methodology, specific definitions are provided. A ‘populated area’ should be understood as a ‘congested area’, as defined in Regulation (EU) No 965/2012, meaning any area within a city, town, or settlement that is substantially used for residential, commercial, or recreational purposes. A ‘rural area’ is used in the context of air risk and refers to the volume of airspace outside a populated area and not within the aerodrome traffic zone of an aerodrome.
chunk_summary: The text explains that the SORA methodology is the primary acceptable means for conducting an operational risk assessment under Article 11, while allowing alternative methods. It outlines when standard scenarios or predefined risk assessments may replace a full assessment and clarifies their structure, purpose, and limitations. It also highlights the central role of the concept of operations and provides key definitions used in the SORA framework.

chunk_title: SORA Introduction, Robustness Concept, and Roles and Responsibilities
chunk_text:
This text introduces the Specific Operations Risk Assessment (SORA) and explains its intent, scope, key concepts, and the main actors involved. The preface states that SORA is based on a document developed by JARUS and provides a vision for how to safely create, evaluate, and conduct an unmanned aircraft system (UAS) operation. It provides a methodology to guide both the UAS operator and the competent authority in determining whether a UAS operation can be conducted safely. It is explicitly not meant to be used as a checklist and is not expected to provide answers to all challenges related to UAS integration in airspace. Instead, it functions as a tailoring guide that helps a UAS operator find the best-fit mitigation means to reduce risk to an acceptable level. Because of this tailoring approach, it does not include prescriptive requirements, but rather defines safety objectives that must be met at different levels of robustness, commensurate with the level of risk. The text also notes that SORA is intended to inspire UAS operators and competent authorities and to highlight the benefits of a harmonised risk assessment methodology, with feedback from real-life operations forming the backbone of future revisions.

The purpose section explains that SORA proposes a methodology to serve as an acceptable means of demonstrating compliance with Article 11 of the UAS Regulation by evaluating risks and determining the acceptability of a proposed UAS operation within the ‘specific’ category. It explains that the ‘specific’ category cannot automatically rely on the safety and performance data established by the large number of unmanned aircraft operating in the ‘open’ category, due to operational differences and increased levels of risk. SORA therefore provides a consistent approach to assessing additional risks linked to expanded and new UAS operations that are not covered by the ‘open’ category. It also clarifies that SORA is not intended to be a one-stop-shop for full integration of all UAS types in all airspace classes. The methodology may be applied where traditional aircraft certification approaches—approving the design, issuing an airworthiness approval, and issuing a type certificate—may not be appropriate because an applicant wishes to operate a UAS in a limited or restricted manner. It may also support activities needed to determine associated airworthiness requirements, on the assumption that safety objectives set forth in, or derived from, those applicable to the ‘certified’ category are consistent with those set forth or derived for the ‘specific’ category. The methodology is described as being based on a holistic or total system safety, risk-based assessment model that evaluates risks for a given UAS operation by considering threats associated with a specified hazard, relevant design aspects, and proposed operational mitigations. SORA helps evaluate risks systematically and determine the boundaries required for safe operation. It allows the applicant to determine acceptable risk levels and validate that proposed operations comply with those levels, while also allowing the competent authority to gain confidence that the operator can conduct the operation safely. To avoid repetitive individual approvals, EASA will apply the methodology to define ‘standard scenarios’ or ‘predefined risk assessments’ for identified types of ConOps with known hazards and acceptable risk mitigations. The processes and values in the document are intended to guide the UAS operator in performing a risk assessment in accordance with Article 11 of the UAS Regulation.

The applicability section states that the methodology is aimed at evaluating safety risks for UAS operations of any class, size, or type, including military, experimental, research and development, and prototyping operations, and is particularly suited—though not limited—to ‘specific’ operations where a hazard and risk assessment are required. Safety risks associated with collisions between unmanned aircraft and manned aircraft are within scope, while the risk of collisions between two unmanned aircraft, or between an unmanned aircraft and an unmanned aircraft carrying people, is noted as something to be addressed in future revisions. The carriage of people or payloads on board the UAS that introduce additional hazards, such as weapons, is explicitly excluded from the methodology’s scope in the event of a mishap. Security aspects are excluded when they go beyond those confined to the airworthiness of the systems, with the example of protection from unlawful electromagnetic interference. Privacy and financial aspects are also excluded. The text notes that SORA can be used to support waiving regulatory requirements applicable to the operation if it can be demonstrated that the operation can be conducted with an acceptable level of safety. It further states that, in addition to performing SORA in accordance with the UAS Regulation, the UAS operator must ensure compliance with all other regulatory requirements applicable to the operation that are not necessarily addressed by SORA.

Key concepts and definitions include a semantic model and the concept of robustness. The semantic model is presented as requiring standardised terminology for phases of operation, procedures, and operational volumes to facilitate effective communication of all SORA aspects. It states that Figure 1 provides consistent use of terms for all users and that Figure 2 provides a graphical representation to help understanding. The introduction to robustness explains that any risk mitigation or operational safety objective can be demonstrated at different levels of robustness, and SORA proposes three levels—low, medium, and high—commensurate with risk. Robustness is achieved by combining the level of integrity, described as the safety gain provided by each mitigation, with the level of assurance, described as the method of proof that the claimed safety gain has been achieved, and both are risk-based. Activities to substantiate integrity are detailed in Annexes B, C, D, and E, which provide guidance material or reference industry standards and practices where applicable. General guidance for assurance is then provided: a low level of assurance is where the applicant simply declares that the required integrity has been achieved; a medium level of assurance is where the applicant provides supporting evidence that integrity has been achieved, typically through testing for technical mitigations or proof of experience for human-related mitigations; and a high level of assurance is where achieved integrity has been found acceptable by a competent third party. The text states that specific criteria in the annexes take precedence over the general criteria and notes that Table 1 provides guidance to determine robustness based on integrity and assurance. An example is given that if an applicant demonstrates a medium level of integrity with a low level of assurance, the overall robustness is considered low, and robustness is always equal to the lowest level of either integrity or assurance.

The roles and responsibilities section identifies key actors that may need to interact during different phases of the SORA process. The UAS operator is described as responsible for safe operation of the UAS and therefore for the safety risk analysis. In accordance with Article 5 of the UAS Regulation, the UAS operator must substantiate safety by performing the specific operational and risk assessment except in cases defined by Article 5, and supporting material may be provided by third parties such as manufacturers, U-space service providers, and others. The UAS operator obtains an operational authorisation from the competent authority or ANSP. It is stated that a UAS operator with a LUC cannot be granted the privilege to assess compliance with design requirements when a UAS with a design verification report or a (restricted) type certificate is required.

The applicant is identified as the party seeking operational approval and becomes the UAS operator once the operation is approved. The UAS manufacturer is defined as the party that designs and or produces the UAS and is described as having unique design evidence, such as evidence for system performance, system architecture, software and hardware development documentation, and test or analysis documentation, which may be shared with UAS operators or the competent authority to support the safety case. The text notes that a potential UAS manufacturer may also use SORA to target design objectives for specific or generalised operations and that these design objectives may be complemented by certification specifications or industry consensus standards if acceptable to EASA to obtain airworthiness approvals. A component manufacturer is similarly defined as designing and or producing components and holding unique design evidence that may be shared to substantiate a safety case.

The competent authority is defined as the authority designated by the Member State under Article 17 of the UAS Regulation to assess the safety case and issue operational authorisation under Article 12. The competent authority may accept a SORA submission in whole or in part, and the applicant may need to consult the authority to ensure consistent application or interpretation of steps. The competent authority must oversee the UAS operator under Article 18. The text explains that, under Regulation (EU) 2018/1139, EASA is the competent authority in the EU to verify compliance of UAS design and components with applicable rules, while the Member State’s designated authority verifies compliance with operational requirements and personnel competency. chunk_title: The SORA Process — Introduction to Risk and Process Outline
chunk_text:
This section explains the foundations of risk within the Specific Operations Risk Assessment (SORA) methodology and outlines how the SORA process is structured and applied. Risk is defined in accordance with SAE ARP 4754A and EUROCAE ED-79A as the combination of the frequency or probability of an occurrence and its associated level of severity. This definition is retained throughout the SORA methodology. The consequence of an occurrence is designated as harm of some type.

It is explained that many categories of harm can arise from a single occurrence. However, this document focuses on occurrences of harm, such as a UAS crash, that are short-lived and typically give rise to a near loss of life. Chronic events, such as toxic emissions over a long period of time, are explicitly excluded from the assessment. Within this scope, the categories of harm considered are the potential for fatal injuries to third parties on the ground, fatal injuries to third parties in the air, and damage to critical infrastructure.

It is acknowledged that competent authorities may, when appropriate, consider additional categories of harm, such as disruption of a community, environmental damage, or financial loss. The methodology could also be used to address those additional categories if required.

The text explains that several studies have shown that the amount of energy required to cause fatal injuries in the case of a direct hit is extremely low, in the region of only a few dozen joules. The energy levels involved in the operations addressed by this document are likely to be significantly higher. As a result, the retained harm within the SORA is the potential for fatal injuries. By applying the methodology, the applicant may claim lower lethality either on a case-by-case basis or systematically if permitted by the competent authority, for example in the ‘open’ category.

Fatal injury is described as a well-defined condition that is recognised by authorities in most countries. As a result, the risk of under-reporting fatalities is considered almost non-existent, and the quantification of fatality risk is relatively straightforward. Fatalities are usually measured as the number of deaths within a given time interval, such as a fatal accident rate per million flying hours, or as the number of deaths for a specific circumstance, such as a fatal accident rate per number of take-offs.

By contrast, damage to critical infrastructure is identified as a more complex condition. The quantification of the associated risks may therefore be difficult and may require cooperation with the organisation responsible for that infrastructure.

The SORA process outline explains that the methodology provides a logical and structured process to analyse the proposed concept of operations and to establish an adequate level of confidence that the operation can be conducted with an acceptable level of risk. The methodology is supported by ten steps, each of which is described in subsequent sections and further detailed, where necessary, in the relevant annexes.

The SORA focuses primarily on the assessment of air risk and ground risk. In addition to these, a separate risk assessment of critical infrastructure should also be performed. This assessment should be carried out in cooperation with the organisation responsible for the infrastructure, as that organisation is best placed to understand the associated threats. The ten steps of the risk model are illustrated in Figure 3, and Figure 4 provides an overall understanding of how to arrive at an air risk class for a given operation.

Before starting the SORA process, a pre-application evaluation is required. The applicant should first verify that the proposed operation is feasible and not subject to specific exclusions by the competent authority or already covered by a standard scenario. The applicant should verify whether the operation falls under the ‘open’ category, whether it is covered by a standard scenario included in the appendix to the UAS Regulation or by a predefined risk assessment published by EASA, whether it falls under the ‘certified’ category, or whether it is subject to a specific no-go decision from the competent authority. If none of these cases applies, the SORA process should be applied.
chunk_summary: This section defines risk within the SORA as the combination of probability and severity and focuses on short-lived occurrences that may result in fatal injuries or damage to critical infrastructure. It explains how risk is quantified and why fatal injury is the primary retained harm. It also outlines the structure of the SORA process, including its ten-step framework and the requirement for a pre-application evaluation before applying the methodology.

chunk_title: Step #1 of the SORA Process: Concept of Operations Description
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #1 of the Specific Operations Risk Assessment process, which focuses on the description of the Concept of Operations, commonly referred to as the ConOps. The first requirement is that the applicant collects and provides all relevant technical, operational, and system information necessary to assess the risks associated with the intended unmanned aircraft system operation. A detailed framework for how this information should be collected and presented is provided in Annex A. The ConOps description is identified as the foundation for all subsequent activities in the SORA process and is expected to be as accurate and detailed as possible.

The ConOps is required to do more than simply describe the operation itself. It must also provide insight into the UAS operator’s operational safety culture and explain how and when interaction with the air navigation service provider will occur. When defining the ConOps, the UAS operator is expected to give due consideration to all steps of the SORA process, including applicable mitigations and operational safety objectives, as referenced in Figures 3 and 4.

The development of the ConOps is described as an iterative process. As the SORA process is applied, additional mitigations and operational limitations may be identified. These may require further technical details, procedures, or other information to be added to or updated within the ConOps. The process should ultimately result in a comprehensive Concept of Operations that fully and accurately reflects the proposed operation as it is intended to be conducted.
chunk_summary: Step #1 of the SORA process establishes the Concept of Operations as the basis for all risk assessment activities. The ConOps must comprehensively describe the operation, the safety culture of the operator, and interactions with external stakeholders such as the ANSP. It is developed iteratively and refined as mitigations and limitations are identified, culminating in a complete and accurate description of the intended UAS operation.

chunk_title: Step #2 of the SORA Process: Determination of the Intrinsic UAS Ground Risk Class
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #2 of the SORA process, which establishes the intrinsic ground risk class of a UAS operation. The intrinsic ground risk relates to the risk of a person being struck by the unmanned aircraft in the event of a loss of control, assuming a reasonable level of safety. The purpose of this step is to characterise the unmitigated ground risk before applying additional risk reductions.

To determine the intrinsic ground risk class, the applicant must identify the maximum characteristic dimension of the unmanned aircraft. Examples of this dimension include wingspan for fixed-wing aircraft, blade diameter for rotorcraft, or the maximum overall dimension for multicopters. This characteristic dimension is considered together with knowledge of the intended operational scenario.

The applicant must also define the area at risk during the operation, referred to as the area of operation. This includes the operational volume, which consists of the flight geography and the contingency volume. In defining the operational volume, the applicant should consider the position-keeping capability of the UAS in four dimensions, including latitude, longitude, height, and time. Specific factors to be addressed include navigation accuracy, flight technical error, path definition errors such as map inaccuracies, and system latencies. The area of operation must also identify whether it is a controlled ground area and must include an associated ground risk buffer. The ground risk buffer must follow at least a one-to-one rule relative to operating altitude, or, for rotary-wing aircraft, be defined using a ballistic methodology acceptable to the competent authority.

The intrinsic ground risk class is determined by combining the applicable operational scenario with the maximum characteristic dimension that drives the lethal area of the UAS. This relationship is illustrated in the referenced table used for classification. If there is a mismatch between the characteristic dimension and the typical kinetic energy expected for the operation, the applicant is required to provide justification for the selected classification.

Operational scenarios are used to categorise operations based on increasing numbers of people at risk. These scenarios may be assessed using qualitative criteria, quantitative criteria, or a combination of both, to determine whether an operation takes place over sparsely populated areas, populated areas, or assemblies of people. For qualitative assessment, the volume used to classify the operation includes both the operational volume and the ground risk buffer, which together determine the intrinsic ground risk class. Guidance is provided on the definition of assemblies of people, and an operation is considered to take place over a populated area when assemblies of people are not present but the area is substantially used for residential, commercial, or recreational purposes.

Extended visual line-of-sight operations are treated as beyond visual line-of-sight operations for the purpose of determining the intrinsic ground risk class. Controlled ground areas are recognised as a strategic means of reducing ground risk, provided that procedures ensure no uninvolved persons are present within the defined area of operation. Operations occurring in populated environments cannot be intrinsically classified as sparsely populated, even when the footprint lies within special risk areas such as rivers, railways, or industrial estates, although claims for reduced density or shelter may be made later in the SORA process.

Operations that do not correspond to a defined intrinsic ground risk class are not supported by the SORA methodology. When evaluating the typical kinetic energy expected, the applicant should generally use cruise airspeed for fixed-wing aircraft and terminal velocity for other aircraft, with additional considerations applied to specific designs where necessary. The nominal crash area is normally estimated based on aircraft size and energy, but non-typical design aspects such as fuel load, high-energy rotors or propellers, material properties, or frangibility may significantly affect the lethal area and justify adjustment of the intrinsic ground risk class. Industry standards or dedicated research may be used to support such assessments.
chunk_summary: Step #2 of the SORA process defines the intrinsic ground risk of a UAS operation by assessing the likelihood of a person being struck following a loss of control. The classification is based on aircraft size, kinetic energy, operational scenario, and the defined area of operation, including buffers and controlled areas. This step establishes the unmitigated ground risk that forms the basis for later application of risk reduction measures.

chunk_title: Step #3 Final Ground Risk Class Determination and Overview of the Air Risk Process
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #3 of the ground risk process in the SORA methodology, which concerns the final determination of the Ground Risk Class (GRC), followed by an overview of the air risk process.

The final GRC determination is based on the principle that the intrinsic risk of a person being struck by a UAS in the event of a loss of control can be controlled and reduced through the application of mitigations. These mitigations directly influence the safety objectives of the operation, making their robustness critical, particularly for technical ground-risk mitigations such as emergency parachute systems.

The final GRC is established by assessing the availability and robustness of applicable mitigations. A predefined list of potential mitigations is associated with relative correction factors, where positive values increase the GRC and negative values decrease it. All mitigations must be applied in numerical sequence to complete the assessment. Additional guidance on estimating mitigation robustness is provided elsewhere, and competent authorities may define further mitigations and corresponding correction factors.

When applying mitigation M1, which is intended to reduce the number of people at risk, the GRC cannot be reduced below the lowest value in the applicable category. This limitation reflects the fact that the number of people at risk cannot be reduced below that associated with a controlled ground area. Mitigation M2 is intended to reduce the energy absorbed by people on the ground upon impact.

An illustrative example is provided involving a 2.5-metre UAS operating in visual line-of-sight over a sparsely populated area. In this case, the intrinsic GRC is 3. The applicant applies mitigation M1 with medium robustness, resulting in a claimed reduction of 2. However, due to the lower bound for that category, the GRC is reduced only to 2. The applicant then applies mitigation M2 using a parachute system, achieving an additional reduction of 1 and resulting in a GRC of 1. Mitigation M3, consisting of an emergency response plan developed to medium robustness, does not provide any further reduction. The final GRC is therefore calculated by summing the correction factors and adjusting the intrinsic GRC accordingly.

If the final GRC exceeds a value of 7, the operation is not supported by the SORA process. In general, a quantitative mitigation approach allows a reduction of one GRC point when the applied mitigation reduces the operational risk by approximately a factor of ten, corresponding to a ninety percent risk reduction. Such quantitative criteria should be used to validate claimed risk reductions when applying the relevant annex.

The air risk process uses the operational airspace defined in the concept of operations as the basis for evaluating the intrinsic risk of a mid-air collision, which is expressed as an Air Risk Category. This category may be reduced through the application of strategic and tactical mitigations. Strategic mitigations, such as operating within specific time periods or boundaries, may lower the air risk category. Additional guidance on estimating mitigation robustness is provided elsewhere, and competent authorities may define further mitigations and corresponding correction factors.

When applying mitigation M1, which is intended to reduce the number of people at risk, the GRC cannot be reduced below the lowest value in the applicable category. This limitation reflects the fact that the number of people at risk cannot be reduced below that associated with a controlled ground area. chunk_title: Step #4 — Determination of the Initial Air Risk Class (ARC)
chunk_text:
This section describes how the initial air risk class, referred to as ARC, is determined within the SORA process. It explains that the competent authority, an air navigation service provider, or a U-space service provider may choose to directly map airspace collision risks using airspace characterisation studies. Such studies may result in static or dynamic air collision risk maps that directly indicate the initial ARC for a specific volume of airspace. When these maps are made available, the applicant is expected to use them to determine the initial ARC and then proceed directly to the application of strategic mitigations in the subsequent step in order to reduce that initial ARC.

In the absence of such a direct air collision risk mapping service, the airspace is categorised into thirteen aggregated collision risk categories. These categories are characterised by several key attributes: the altitude of the operation, whether the airspace is controlled or uncontrolled, whether the operation takes place in an airport or heliport environment or outside such environments, whether the airspace is over an urban or rural area, and whether the airspace is atypical, such as segregated airspace, or typical civil airspace. To assign the appropriate ARC for the intended UAS operation, the applicant is required to use the decision tree provided in Figure 4.

The ARC itself is defined as a qualitative classification of the rate at which a UAS would encounter a manned aircraft in typical generalised civil airspace. It represents an initial assignment of aggregated collision risk for the airspace before any mitigations are applied. The text highlights that the actual collision risk within a specific local operational volume may differ significantly from this generalised assessment. Such differences may be addressed through the application of strategic mitigations to reduce the ARC, although the application of these mitigations is optional at this stage of the process.

It is noted that the static and generalised risk represented by the ARC is intentionally conservative, meaning it errs on the side of safety. However, there may be situations in which this conservative assessment is not sufficient. In these cases, both the competent authority and the UAS operator must take care to fully understand the operational volume and the circumstances under which the assumptions used in the decision tree may no longer be valid. In some situations, the competent authority may raise the ARC assigned to the operational volume to a level higher than that suggested by the decision tree. Consultation with the ANSP is recommended to ensure that all assumptions regarding the operational volume are accurate.

The text further defines the meaning of the ARC levels. ARC-a is generally associated with airspace in which the risk of collision between a UAS and a manned aircraft is considered acceptable without the need for any tactical mitigation. ARC-b, ARC-c, and ARC-d correspond to airspace volumes with progressively increasing risks of collision between a UAS and a manned aircraft.

Finally, it is explained that during a UAS operation, the operational volume may extend across multiple airspace environments. The applicant is therefore required to perform an air risk assessment that covers the entire range of the operational volume. An example of an operation spanning multiple airspace environments is provided in Annex C.
chunk_summary: This step explains how the initial air risk class is assigned based on generalised airspace collision risk before mitigations are applied. It allows for direct use of airspace collision risk maps where available or, alternatively, use of a decision tree based on airspace characteristics. The ARC provides a conservative starting point for air risk assessment and may be adjusted or reduced through strategic mitigations.

chunk_title: Step #5 — Application of Strategic Mitigations to Determine the Residual Air Risk Class
chunk_text:
This step explains how strategic mitigations may be applied to refine the initial air risk class and determine the residual air risk class, referred to as the residual ARC. It reiterates that the ARC is a generalised qualitative classification of the rate at which a UAS would encounter a manned aircraft within a given airspace environment. This generalised classification is intentionally conservative and is based on typical characteristics of the airspace rather than the specific details of a local operation.

It is recognised that the actual collision risk within the specific operational volume of a UAS may differ from the collision risk represented by the generalised initial ARC. Local factors such as traffic density variations, operational constraints, or specific airspace arrangements may result in a lower or, in some cases, different risk profile compared to the generalised assumption.

If the applicant considers that the generalised initial ARC assigned to the operation is too high for the conditions present in the local operational volume, the applicant should apply the ARC reduction process described in Annex C. This process allows the applicant to justify a reduction of the initial ARC by demonstrating the effect of strategic mitigations that lower the likelihood of encountering manned aircraft.

If, on the other hand, the applicant considers that the generalised initial ARC accurately reflects the collision risk within the local operational volume, then no reduction is applied. In this case, the initially assigned ARC directly becomes the residual ARC. The application of strategic mitigations at this stage is therefore optional and dependent on whether the applicant seeks to reduce the initial ARC based on local operational conditions.
chunk_summary: This step allows an applicant to reassess the initial air risk class using local operational conditions. If justified, strategic mitigations may be applied to reduce the ARC using the process in Annex C. If no reduction is justified, the initial ARC is retained as the residual ARC.

chunk_title: Step #6 of the SORA Process: TMPR and Robustness Levels
chunk_text:
This content explains Step #6 of the SORA process, which addresses Tactical Mitigation Performance Requirements, known as TMPR, and their associated robustness levels. Tactical mitigations are applied to reduce any residual risk of a mid-air collision so that the applicable airspace safety objective is achieved. These mitigations may take the form of visual ‘see and avoid’ operations conducted under visual line of sight, or they may rely on technical systems that provide alternative means of achieving the airspace safety objective, such as detect-and-avoid systems or combinations of multiple detect-and-avoid systems. Annex D is referenced as providing the method for applying these tactical mitigations.

Operations conducted under visual line of sight are considered an acceptable tactical mitigation for collision risk for all air risk classes. Even so, the UAS operator is advised to consider additional measures to increase situational awareness of air traffic in the vicinity of the operational volume. Flights conducted under visual line of sight are not required to meet TMPR or TMPR robustness requirements. In operations consisting of multiple flight segments, only those segments conducted beyond visual line of sight are required to meet TMPR and robustness requirements. Extended visual line of sight operations generally follow the same requirements as visual line of sight operations, but may include additional constraints. In particular, the verification and communication latency between the remote pilot and observers must be less than 15 seconds.

For visual line of sight operations, the applicant is expected to have a documented de-confliction scheme. This scheme explains the methods used for traffic detection and defines the criteria applied to decide when to avoid incoming traffic. If observers are used for detection, the phraseology to be used must also be described. It is assumed that observers are generally unable to detect traffic beyond two nautical miles, although this range is not fixed and may vary depending on factors such as atmospheric conditions, aircraft size, geometry, and closing rate. As a result, the UAS operator may need to adjust the operation or procedures accordingly.

For operations other than visual line of sight, the applicant uses the residual air risk class together with the referenced table to determine the applicable TMPR. A high TMPR applies to airspace where manned aircraft encounter rates are high and or where strategic mitigations are limited, resulting in a high residual collision risk. In such airspace, the UAS may operate in integrated airspace and must comply with applicable operating rules and procedures without reducing capacity, decreasing safety, negatively affecting manned aircraft operations, or increasing risk to airspace users or people and property on the ground. The required performance and variety of tactical mitigations are higher than for other air risk classes, and routine operations in this environment are expected to comply with recognised detect-and-avoid system standards, such as those developed by RTCA SC-228 or EUROCAE WG-105.

A medium TMPR applies where the likelihood of encountering manned aircraft is reasonable and or where strategic mitigations are of medium effectiveness. Operations at this level are typically supported by systems already used in aviation to aid the remote pilot in detecting other aircraft, or by systems designed for aviation and built to a corresponding level of robustness. Traffic avoidance manoeuvres at this level may be more advanced than those used for low TMPR operations.

A low TMPR applies where the probability of encountering manned aircraft is low but not negligible, and where strategic mitigations address most of the risk, resulting in a low residual collision risk. Operations at this level may rely on technology that assists the remote pilot in detecting other traffic but is built to lower standards. For example, for operations below 120 metres, traffic avoidance manoeuvres are generally expected to rely on rapid descent to altitudes where manned aircraft are not expected to operate.

No performance requirement applies in airspace where the manned aircraft encounter rate is expected to be extremely low. In such airspace, there is no requirement for a TMPR, as the risk of collision between a UAS and a manned aircraft is considered acceptable without additional tactical mitigation. Examples include very remote regions where manned aircraft density is extremely low. Annex D provides further information on how to satisfy TMPR objectives based on available tactical mitigations and the required level of robustness.

The content also explains that additional airspace or operational requirements may be imposed by the competent authority or the air navigation service provider as safety and operational issues arise. Air risk classes are described as generalised qualitative classifications, and local circumstances such as special events may invalidate the assumed aircraft density. Both the competent authority and the UAS operator are expected to understand local airspace and traffic flows and to develop means to alert operators to changes in airspace conditions. Because the SORA cannot cover every possible airspace, operational, or equipment requirement, applicants and competent authorities must work together to identify and address additional requirements. The SORA process should not be used to justify operations in airspace unless the UAS is equipped with the required equipment for that airspace, except where specific exemptions are granted by the competent authority. Operations in controlled airspace, airport or heliport environments, or transponder mandatory zones are likely to require prior approval from the air navigation service provider, and early coordination with the authority is expected.
chunk_summary: Step #6 of the SORA process defines how tactical mitigations and TMPR are applied to manage mid-air collision risk. Visual line of sight operations generally do not require TMPR, while beyond visual line of sight operations must meet TMPR levels based on residual air risk. Increasing TMPR levels correspond to higher encounter rates and require more robust detect-and-avoid capabilities and closer coordination with authorities and air navigation service providers.

chunk_title: Step #7 SAIL Determination in the SORA Process
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #7 of the SORA methodology, which concerns the determination of the Specific Assurance and Integrity Level, known as the SAIL. The SAIL parameter consolidates the outcomes of both the ground risk analysis and the air risk analysis and drives the activities required for the operation. It represents the level of confidence that the unmanned aircraft system operation will remain under control.

Once the final Ground Risk Class and the residual Air Risk Category have been determined, the SAIL associated with the proposed concept of operations can be derived. This step links the assessed ground and air risks into a single parameter that reflects the overall operational risk profile.

The level of confidence that the operation will remain under control is expressed through the SAIL. The SAIL is not a quantitative value. Instead, it corresponds to the operational safety objectives that must be complied with, as referenced in Table 6, the description of the activities that may support compliance with those objectives, and the evidence demonstrating that the objectives have been satisfied.
chunk_summary: The SAIL determination combines the final ground and air risk results into a single parameter representing confidence in operational control. It is derived after establishing the final GRC and residual ARC. Rather than being quantitative, the SAIL defines applicable safety objectives, supporting activities, and required evidence.

chunk_title: Step #8 of the SORA Process: Identification of Operational Safety Objectives
chunk_text:
This content explains Step #8 of the SORA process, which focuses on identifying the operational safety objectives, known as OSOs, and determining their required level of robustness. This step uses the Specific Assurance and Integrity Level, or SAIL, as the basis for evaluating the defences that are needed within the operation. The OSOs represent these defences and are used to ensure that the risks identified in earlier steps are adequately controlled.

The determination of the required OSOs and their robustness is supported by a qualitative methodology provided in the referenced table. Within this methodology, four designations are used. An OSO marked as optional means that it may be applied at the discretion of the operator. An OSO marked with a low recommendation indicates that it is recommended with low robustness. A medium recommendation indicates that it is recommended with medium robustness, and a high recommendation indicates that it is recommended with high robustness. The OSOs are organised according to the type of threat they are intended to mitigate, which means that the same OSO may appear more than once where it addresses different threats.

The table of OSOs represents a consolidated list of safety objectives that have historically been applied to ensure safe UAS operations. It reflects the accumulated experience of numerous experts and is intended to serve as a reliable starting point for determining the safety objectives required for a specific operation. While this table provides a common baseline, the competent authorities responsible for issuing the operational authorisation retain the ability to define additional OSOs and to specify the associated level of robustness for a given SAIL. A note clarifies that, in the case of experimental flights investigating new technical solutions, the competent authority may accept that recognised standards are not met.
chunk_summary: Step #8 uses the assigned SAIL to identify the operational safety objectives required to defend against identified risks. The OSOs and their robustness levels are selected using a qualitative methodology based on established experience. Competent authorities may supplement these objectives as needed, particularly for specific or experimental operations.

chunk_title: Step #9 of the SORA Process: Adjacent Area and Airspace Considerations
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #9 of the SORA process, which addresses the risks associated with a loss of control of a UAS operation that could result in an infringement of adjacent ground areas or adjacent airspace. These adjacent areas may differ depending on the phase of flight, and the objective is to ensure that such risks are adequately controlled through containment measures.

The concept of basic containment is introduced with a fundamental safety requirement stating that no probable failure of the UAS or of any external system supporting the operation should lead to the aircraft operating outside the defined operational volume. The term “probable” is understood qualitatively as a failure anticipated to occur one or more times during the entire system or operational life of an item. A failure is defined as an occurrence that prevents a component, part, or element from functioning as intended, while errors may cause failures but are not considered failures themselves. Certain structural or mechanical failures may be excluded if it can be demonstrated that those parts were designed according to aviation industry best practices. Compliance with the basic containment requirement must be substantiated through a design and installation appraisal that includes consideration of design and installation features such as independence, separation, and redundancy, although these features are not mandatory. The appraisal must also address relevant particular risks associated with the concept of operations, such as hail, ice, snow, or electromagnetic interference. The competent authority may accept a declaration of integrity from the applicant, provided that supporting evidence is available.

Enhanced containment requirements apply in specific operational situations. These include operations where adjacent areas contain assemblies of people unless the UAS is already approved for such operations, or where adjacent airspace is classified as ARC-d unless the residual ARC of the airspace within the operational volume is already ARC-d. Enhanced containment also applies when operations take place in a populated area where M1 mitigation has been applied to lower the ground risk class, or when operating within a controlled ground area.

Enhanced containment introduces additional safety requirements. The UAS must be designed to standards considered adequate by the competent authority or in accordance with acceptable means of compliance. Under these conditions, the probability of the unmanned aircraft leaving the operational volume must be less than one event per ten thousand flight hours, and no single failure of the UAS or any supporting external system may result in operation outside the ground risk buffer. Compliance with these requirements must be substantiated through analysis or test data with supporting evidence. Furthermore, software and airborne electronic hardware whose development errors could directly lead to operation outside the ground risk buffer must be developed to an industry standard or methodology recognised as adequate by EASA.

For unmanned aircraft with a maximum characteristic dimension not exceeding three metres and operated up to SAIL II, the competent authority may accept a declaration of compliance with the applicable means of compliance for Light-UAS.2511. For configurations exceeding the applicability of such means of compliance, the competent authority may still accept declarations supported by evidence, accept alternative means of compliance proposed by the applicant, or require the use of a UAS for which EASA has verified the claimed integrity. It is noted that means of compliance applicable to different UAS configurations are under development, and interim arrangements may be defined by competent authorities for special configurations such as tethered drones.

The text emphasises that it is not possible to anticipate all local situations when defining adjacent areas and adjacent airspace. chunk_title: Step #10 — Comprehensive Safety Portfolio in the SORA Process
chunk_text:
This content describes Step #10 of the SORA process, referred to as the comprehensive safety portfolio. This step explains how the overall SORA methodology brings together all relevant mitigations and safety objectives to provide confidence that a UAS operation can be conducted safely.

The SORA process provides a structured methodology for the applicant, the competent authority, and the air navigation service provider. This methodology includes a series of mitigations and safety objectives that must be considered. These include mitigations used to modify the intrinsic ground risk class, strategic mitigations applied to the initial air risk category, tactical mitigations applied to the residual air risk category, considerations related to adjacent areas and adjacent airspace, and the operational safety objectives.

When the mitigations and safety objectives required by the SORA process are satisfactorily substantiated, they collectively provide a sufficient level of confidence that the proposed operation can be safely conducted. This substantiation forms the core of the safety case supporting the operation.

The UAS operator is also expected to address any additional requirements that are not identified by the SORA process. Examples of such requirements include security considerations and environmental protection. In doing so, the operator should identify and involve the relevant stakeholders, such as environmental protection agencies or national security bodies. Although activities performed within the SORA process will likely address some of these additional needs, they may not always be sufficient.

Finally, the UAS operator is responsible for ensuring consistency between the SORA safety case and the actual operational conditions at the time of the flight. This ensures that the assumptions, mitigations, and objectives defined during the assessment remain valid during real-world operations.

chunk_title: List of STSs published as ‘Appendix 1 for standard scenarios supporting a declaration’ to the Annex to the UAS Regulation
chunk_text:
The information describes two standard scenarios, identified as STS-01 and STS-02, both published in June 2020, which support a declaration under the Annex to the UAS Regulation. STS-01 applies to unmanned aircraft systems bearing a C5 class marking, with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and a maximum take-off mass of up to 25 kilograms. This scenario is conducted under visual line of sight. The operation takes place over a controlled ground area that might be located in a populated area. The maximum range from the remote pilot is limited to visual line of sight, and the maximum permitted height is 120 metres. Operations may be conducted in controlled or uncontrolled airspace, provided there is a low risk of encounter with manned aircraft. No additional notes are provided.

STS-02 applies to unmanned aircraft systems bearing a C6 class marking, also with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and a maximum take-off mass of up to 25 kilograms. This scenario allows beyond visual line of sight operations. The operation takes place over a controlled ground area that is entirely located in a sparsely populated area. The maximum range from the remote pilot is up to 2 kilometres when an air observer is used, or 1 kilometre if no air observer is used. The maximum permitted height is 120 metres. As with STS-01, operations may be conducted in controlled or uncontrolled airspace, provided there is a low risk of encounter with manned aircraft. No additional notes are provided.

chunk_title: List of PDRAs published as AMC to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation
chunk_text:
The information presents five predefined risk assessments, identified as PDRA-S01, PDRA-S02, PDRA-G01, PDRA-G02, and PDRA-G03, each linked to an acceptable means of compliance to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. PDRA-S01, edition 1.1 dated January 2022, applies to unmanned aircraft systems with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and a take-off mass of up to 25 kilograms. Operations are conducted under visual line of sight over a controlled ground area that might be located in a populated area. The maximum range from the remote pilot is limited to visual line of sight, the maximum height is 150 metres, and the airspace may be controlled or uncontrolled with a low risk of encounter with manned aircraft. This scenario is associated with AMC4.

PDRA-S02, edition 1.1 dated January 2022, also applies to unmanned aircraft systems with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and a take-off mass of up to 25 kilograms, but allows beyond visual line of sight operations. The overflown area is a controlled ground area that is entirely located in a sparsely populated area. The maximum range from the remote pilot is 2 kilometres when an air observer or air observers are used, or 1 kilometre if no air observer is used. The maximum height is 150 metres, and operations may take place in controlled or uncontrolled airspace with a low risk of encounter with manned aircraft. This scenario is linked to AMC5.

PDRA-G01, edition 1.2 dated January 2022, covers unmanned aircraft systems with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and typical kinetic energy of up to 34 kilojoules. Operations are beyond visual line of sight over a sparsely populated area. If no air observer is used, the maximum range from the remote pilot is up to 1 kilometre. The maximum height is 150 metres, defined as the operational volume. The airspace is uncontrolled, with a low risk of encounter with manned aircraft, and this PDRA is associated with AMC2.

PDRA-G02, edition 1.1 dated January 2022, applies to unmanned aircraft systems with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and typical kinetic energy of up to 34 kilojoules. Operations are beyond visual line of sight over a sparsely populated area. The maximum range from the remote pilot is not applicable because a direct command and control link is used. The maximum height is established for the reserved or segregated airspace for the UAS operation. The applicable airspace is reserved or segregated, and this PDRA is linked to AMC3.

PDRA-G03, edition 1.0 dated January 2022, also applies to unmanned aircraft systems with a maximum characteristic dimension of up to 3 metres and typical kinetic energy of up to 34 kilojoules. Operations are beyond visual line of sight over sparsely populated areas. The maximum range from the remote pilot is not applicable due to a direct command and control link. The maximum height is 50 metres from the ground unless the operation takes place in reserved or segregated airspace. Operations may be conducted in controlled or uncontrolled airspace if the height is below 50 metres, otherwise the airspace must be reserved or segregated. This scenario is associated with AMC6.

The PDRAs define clear conditions for operational mode, population density, range, height, airspace, and the applicable acceptable means of compliance.

chunk_title: Determination of the Intrinsic UAS Ground Risk Class
chunk_text:
The information defines how the intrinsic unmanned aircraft system ground risk class is determined based on the maximum UAS characteristic dimension, the typical kinetic energy expected, and the operational scenario. Four size and energy categories are specified. The smallest category covers UAS with a maximum characteristic dimension of 1 metre, approximately 3 feet, and typical kinetic energy below 700 joules, approximately 529 foot-pounds. The next category applies to UAS with a maximum characteristic dimension of 3 metres, approximately 10 feet, and typical kinetic energy below 34 kilojoules, approximately 25 000 foot-pounds. A larger category includes UAS with a maximum characteristic dimension of 8 metres, approximately 25 feet, and typical kinetic energy below 1 084 kilojoules, approximately 800 000 foot-pounds. The largest category applies to UAS with a maximum characteristic dimension greater than 8 metres, approximately 25 feet, and typical kinetic energy greater than 1 084 kilojoules, approximately 800 000 foot-pounds.

For operations conducted under visual line of sight or beyond visual line of sight over a controlled ground area, the intrinsic ground risk class increases from 1 for the smallest UAS category, to 2 for the 3-metre category, to 3 for the 8-metre category, and to 4 for UAS larger than 8 metres. For visual line of sight operations over a sparsely populated area, the intrinsic ground risk class is 2 for the smallest category, 3 for the 3-metre category, 4 for the 8-metre category, and 5 for the largest category. For beyond visual line of sight operations over a sparsely populated area, the intrinsic ground risk class is 3, 4, 5, and 6 respectively as the UAS size and energy increase.

For visual line of sight operations over a populated area, the intrinsic ground risk class is 4 for the smallest UAS category, 5 for the 3-metre category, 6 for the 8-metre category, and 8 for UAS larger than 8 metres. For beyond visual line of sight operations over a populated area, the intrinsic ground risk class increases to 5, 6, 8, and 10 respectively. When operations are conducted over an assembly of people, visual line of sight operations result in an intrinsic ground risk class of 7 for the smallest UAS category, while beyond visual line of sight operations result in an intrinsic ground risk class of 8 for the smallest category. No values are provided for larger UAS categories for operations over an assembly of people.
chunk_summary: The table establishes intrinsic ground risk classes by combining UAS size, expected kinetic energy, and the type of operational environment. Risk values increase with larger aircraft, higher energy, denser populations, and beyond visual line of sight operations. Operations over assemblies of people are assigned particularly high risk classes even for the smallest UAS.

chunk_title: Mitigations for Final GRC Determination
chunk_text:
The information describes three sequential mitigation measures used to determine the final ground risk class for an unmanned aircraft system operation, together with the effect of each mitigation depending on its level of robustness. The first mitigation, identified as M1 and applied as mitigation sequence 1, concerns strategic mitigations for ground risk. When no mitigation is applied, the effect is zero. When applied with low robustness, the ground risk class is reduced by one. When applied with medium robustness, the ground risk class is reduced by two, and when applied with high robustness, it is reduced by four.

The second mitigation, M2, applied as mitigation sequence 2, addresses the reduction of the effects of ground impact. With low or no robustness, this mitigation has no effect on the ground risk class. When applied with medium robustness, it reduces the ground risk class by one, and when applied with high robustness, it reduces the ground risk class by two.

The third mitigation, M3, applied as mitigation sequence 3, relates to having an emergency response plan in place, with the UAS operator validated and effective. With low or no robustness, this mitigation increases the ground risk class by one. When applied with medium robustness, it has no effect, and when applied with high robustness, it reduces the ground risk class by one.

The impact of each mitigation depends on whether it is implemented with low, medium, or high robustness. Strategic mitigations and impact-reduction measures can significantly lower risk, while an effective emergency response plan can further influence the final result.

chunk_title: SAIL Determination
chunk_text:
The information explains how the specific assurance and integrity level, known as SAIL, is assigned to a particular concept of operations by combining the final ground risk class with the residual air risk class. Residual air risk classes are identified as a, b, c, and d, while the final ground risk class ranges from values of two or less up to greater than seven.

When the final ground risk class is two or less, the assigned SAIL is I for residual air risk class a, II for class b, IV for class c, and VI for class d. For a final ground risk class of three, the SAIL is II for residual air risk classes a and b, IV for class c, and VI for class d. When the final ground risk class is four, the SAIL becomes III for residual air risk classes a and b, IV for class c, and VI for class d.

For a final ground risk class of five, the assigned SAIL is IV for residual air risk classes a, b, and c, and VI for class d. When the final ground risk class is six, the SAIL is V for residual air risk classes a, b, and c, and VI for class d. When the final ground risk class is seven, the SAIL is VI for all residual air risk classes a, b, c, and d. If the final ground risk class is greater than seven, the operation is classified as a Category C operation rather than being assigned a SAIL value.
chunk_summary: The table defines a structured method to assign a SAIL based on combined ground and air risk levels. Higher ground risk or higher residual air risk leads to higher SAIL values, indicating more stringent safety assurance requirements. Operations exceeding a final ground risk class of seven fall outside the SAIL framework and are treated as Category C operations.

chunk_title: Recommended Operational Safety Objectives (OSOs)
chunk_text:
The information defines a set of recommended operational safety objectives, identified as OSO numbers in line with Annex E, and links each objective to the required level of robustness depending on the assigned specific assurance and integrity level from I to VI. The robustness indicators used are O for optional, L for low robustness, M for medium robustness, and H for high robustness.

Under the category of technical issues with the UAS, OSO#01 requires ensuring that the UAS operator is competent and or proven. This objective is optional at SAIL I, requires low robustness at SAIL II, medium robustness at SAIL III, and high robustness at SAIL IV, V, and VI. OSO#02 addresses UAS manufactured by a competent and or proven entity and is optional at SAIL I and II, low robustness at SAIL III, medium robustness at SAIL IV, and high robustness at SAIL V and VI. OSO#03 concerns UAS maintained by a competent and or proven entity, requiring low robustness at SAIL I and II, medium robustness at SAIL III and IV, and high robustness at SAIL V and VI. OSO#04 covers UAS developed to authority recognised design standards and is optional at SAIL I, II, and III, low robustness at SAIL IV, medium robustness at SAIL V, and high robustness at SAIL VI. OSO#05 requires that the UAS is designed considering system safety and reliability and is optional at SAIL I and II, low robustness at SAIL III, medium robustness at SAIL IV, and high robustness at SAIL V and VI.
