chunk_title: Conditions for Personnel in Charge of Duties Essential to the UAS Operation
chunk_text:
This section sets out the conditions applicable to personnel who perform duties essential to the UAS operation. The UAS operator is required to keep and maintain up-to-date records of all relevant qualifications and training courses completed by the remote pilot and other personnel with essential operational duties, as well as by maintenance staff. These records must be retained for at least three years after the individuals cease to be employed by the organisation or change position within it. The operator declares compliance and confirms that record-keeping data are available for inspection at the request of the competent authority.

The remote pilot must have the authority to cancel or delay any or all flight operations if certain conditions arise. These include situations where the safety of persons is jeopardised, where property on the ground is at risk, where other airspace users are in jeopardy, or where there is a violation of the terms of the operational authorisation. For each of these cases, a reference to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual is requested, and compliance is declared.

Additional requirements apply specifically to the remote pilot. The remote pilot must not perform duties under the influence of psychoactive substances or alcohol, or when unfit due to injury, fatigue, medication, sickness, or other causes. The remote pilot must be familiar with the manufacturer’s instructions provided for the UAS and must ensure that the UA remains clear of clouds. The remote pilot is required to hold a certificate of remote pilot theoretical knowledge in accordance with Attachment A to Chapter I of Appendix 1 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation, issued either by the competent authority or by an entity designated by that authority. In addition, the remote pilot must hold an accreditation or completion certificate for a practical-skills training course applicable to this PDRA, in accordance with Attachment A to Chapter I of Appendix 1 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation.

Where operations are conducted at a height between 120 m and 150 m, the remote pilot must receive additional theoretical knowledge training. This training covers raising awareness about air risk and the existence of other airspace users, checking height determination and limitation devices, using procedures for coordination between the remote pilot and any airspace observers, and using the applicable procedures in case a manned aircraft is detected. The remote pilot must also obtain updated information relevant to the intended operation concerning any geographical zones defined in accordance with Article 15 of the UAS Regulation.

Before starting the UAS operation, the remote pilot must ensure that the UAS is in a safe condition to complete the intended flight safely and, where applicable, check that the direct remote identification is active and up to date. Prior to the operation, the remote pilot must verify that the remote identification system is operational, obtain updated information about applicable geographical zones, ensure again that the UAS is in a safe condition for flight, set the programmable flight volume to keep the UA within the defined flight geography, and verify that the means to terminate the flight and the programmable flight volume functionality are operational.

During the flight, unless supported by airspace observers, the remote pilot must maintain a thorough visual scan of the surrounding airspace to avoid any risk of collision with manned aircraft. The remote pilot must discontinue the flight if the operation poses a risk to other aircraft, people, animals, the environment, or property. The remote pilot must maintain control of the UA except in the case of a loss of the command-and-control link, operate only one UA at a time, not operate the UA from a moving vehicle, and not hand control of the UA over to another control unit. When airspace observers are employed, the remote pilot must inform them in a timely manner of any deviations from the intended flight path or associated timing. The remote pilot must use the contingency procedures defined by the UAS operator for abnormal situations, including cases where there is an indication that the UA may exceed the limits of the flight geography, and must use the emergency procedures defined by the operator, including triggering the means to terminate the flight when there is an indication that the UA may exceed the limits of the operational volume. The remote pilot must also activate the direct remote identification system.

Specific conditions apply to airspace observers. The main responsibilities of airspace observers are laid down in point UAS.STS-02.050 of the Annex to the UAS Regulation. If operations are conducted at a height between 120 m and 150 m, airspace observers must undergo additional theoretical knowledge training. This training includes raising awareness about air risk and the existence of other airspace users, checking height determination and limitation devices, using coordination procedures between the remote pilot and the airspace observers, and using applicable procedures in case a manned aircraft is detected. For these conditions, compliance is declared or marked as not applicable where relevant.
chunk_summary: The conditions define qualification, training, authority, and conduct requirements for remote pilots, maintenance staff, and airspace observers involved in UAS operations. They require robust record-keeping, clear authority to stop unsafe operations, specific certifications and training, and detailed pre-flight and in-flight responsibilities. Additional requirements apply for higher-altitude operations and when airspace observers are used.

chunk_title: Technical Conditions for the UAS under PDRA Characterisation
chunk_text:
This section describes the technical conditions applicable to the unmanned aircraft system. The UAS operator is required to use a UAS that is marked with a class C6 identification label and that complies with the requirements of that class, as defined in Part 17 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945. The operator declares that the UAS is marked with a class C6 identification label, or indicates that this condition is not applicable. This requirement has been applicable since 1 July 2022.

As an alternative to the use of a class C6-marked UAS, the UAS operator may use a UAS that complies with the requirements of Part 16 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945. In this case, the UAS does not need to bear a class C3 or class C6 identification label. The UAS does not need to be exclusively powered by electricity, provided that the UAS operator ensures that the environmental impact caused by the use of non-electric UAS is minimised. The UAS must include a notice published by EASA that provides the applicable limitations and obligations required by the UAS Regulation. If the UAS is privately built, the manufacturer’s instructions must be included; however, information on the operation and maintenance of the UAS, as well as on the training of the remote pilot, must be included in the operations manual.

It is noted that the UAS can comply with point (9) of Part 4 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945 by using an add-on that complies with Part 6 of the Annex to that Regulation. In addition, if the UAS does not bear a physical serial number that is compliant with the standard ANSI/CTA-2063-A for Small Unmanned Aerial Systems Serial Numbers, and/or does not have an integrated system of direct remote identification, it may comply with point (9) of Part 4 of the Annex by using an add-on that complies with Part 6 of the Annex.

Where the UAS is privately built, there may be no identification on the UAS of its maximum take-off mass. In that case, the operator must ensure that the maximum take-off mass of the UAS, in the configuration used before take-off, does not exceed 25 kg. For the technical conditions described in this section, compliance is declared, or marked as not applicable where relevant.
chunk_summary: The technical conditions define how the UAS must comply either through class C6 marking or via an alternative compliance route under Part 16 of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. They address identification, power source considerations, environmental impact, documentation, and remote identification arrangements. Additional notes clarify compliance options for privately built UAS and limits on maximum take-off mass.

chunk_title: PDRA-S01 Scope and Operational Conditions under AMC4 Article 11
chunk_text:
The document is issued by EASA within the Easy Access Rules for Unmanned Aircraft Systems and relates to AMC4 Article 11, which sets rules for conducting an operational risk assessment. It refers specifically to the Predefined Risk Assessment PDRA-S01, Version 1.2, published in the September 2023 edition under ED Decision 2023/012/R, and supports the implementation of Regulation (EU) 2019/947.

The scope explains that PDRA-S01 addresses the same type of unmanned aircraft system operations that are covered by the standard scenario STS-01, as defined in Appendix 1 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation. However, it provides additional flexibility by allowing the UAS operator to use unmanned aircraft that do not need to be marked as class C5.

The PDRA applies to UAS operations conducted with unmanned aircraft having maximum characteristic dimensions of up to 3 metres. These dimensions may include wingspan, rotor diameter or area, or, in the case of a multirotor, the maximum distance between rotor tips. The operations must be conducted within visual line of sight of the remote pilot. They take place over a controlled ground area, which may be located within a populated area.

The operational limitations further specify that flights are conducted below 150 metres above ground level, except when operating close to obstacles. Operations may take place in either controlled or uncontrolled airspace, provided that there is a low probability of encountering manned aircraft.

The document also states that the characterisation and conditions applicable to this predefined risk assessment are summarised in Table PDRA-S01.1, which is referenced but not shown in the visible content.
chunk_summary: This content defines the scope and applicability of PDRA-S01 under AMC4 Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. It outlines the types of UAS operations covered, including size limits, visual line of sight requirements, ground area control, altitude limits, and airspace conditions. The PDRA offers flexibility compared to STS-01 by allowing operations without class C5-marked aircraft.

chunk_title: PDRA-S01 Characterisation and Conditions for UAS Operations
chunk_text:
This content describes the characterisation and operational conditions applicable to PDRA-S01, including assurance levels, conditions to be met, and how integrity and assurance are demonstrated. All listed items are subject to self-declaration by the operator, with integrity demonstrated by referencing the relevant chapter or section of the Operations Manual, and assurance demonstrated through a formal statement of compliance.

Regarding the level of human intervention, no autonomous operations are permitted. The remote pilot must be able to maintain control of the unmanned aircraft at all times, except in the event of a loss of the command-and-control link. The remote pilot is required to operate only one unmanned aircraft at a time, must not operate the aircraft from a moving vehicle, and must not transfer control of the unmanned aircraft to another command unit.

The unmanned aircraft must remain within visual line of sight of the remote pilot at all times. Operations must be conducted over a controlled ground area. When operating a tethered unmanned aircraft, the controlled area must have a radius equal to the tether length plus five metres and be centred on the point on the Earth’s surface where the tether is fixed. The unmanned aircraft is limited to a maximum characteristic dimension of less than three metres, including measures such as wingspan, rotor diameter or area, or the maximum distance between rotor tips in the case of a multirotor.

With respect to flight height, the remote pilot must normally keep the unmanned aircraft within 120 metres from the closest point of the Earth’s surface. The method for measuring distances must be adapted to the geographical characteristics of the terrain, including plains, hills, and mountains. When flying within a horizontal distance of 50 metres from an artificial obstacle taller than 105 metres, the maximum height of the operation may be increased by up to 15 metres above the height of the obstacle, at the request of the entity responsible for that obstacle. When operations are intended to take place above 120 metres and up to 150 metres, a risk buffer must be defined in accordance with point 3.8.

Airspace conditions specify that the unmanned aircraft should be operated either in uncontrolled airspace, unless Member States define different limitations for geographical zones where the probability of encountering manned aircraft is not low, or in controlled airspace following coordination and flight authorisation in accordance with published procedures for the area of operation. These measures must ensure that the probability of encountering manned aircraft remains low. A note clarifies that airspace with an air risk class not higher than ARC-b can be considered as having a low probability of encountering manned aircraft.

Visibility requirements state that flight visibility must allow the remote pilot to conduct the entire flight in visual line of sight.

Additional conditions specify that the unmanned aircraft must not be used to carry dangerous goods. An exception is made for dropping items in connection with agricultural, horticultural, or forestry activities, provided that the carriage of such items does not contravene other applicable regulations. A note further requires the operator to comply with applicable national or international regulations concerning the use of plant protection products, chemicals, dangerous substances, and preparations, including, where applicable, Directive 2009/128/EC establishing a framework for Community action to achieve the sustainable use of pesticides.
chunk_summary: The PDRA-S01 conditions define strict operational limits for UAS operations conducted under self-declaration. They cover human control, visual line of sight, aircraft size, flight height, airspace use, visibility, and restrictions on dangerous goods. Compliance is demonstrated through references in the Operations Manual and a formal declaration of compliance by the operator.

chunk_title: Operational Risk Classification under AMC1 Article 11
chunk_text:
This section presents the operational risk classification of the unmanned aircraft system operation, carried out in accordance with the classification framework defined in AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. The classification consolidates the assessed ground risk and air risk into a final operational risk outcome.

The final ground risk class for the operation is established as GRC 3. This reflects the evaluated level of risk to people and property on the ground after considering the characteristics of the operation and any applicable mitigations.

The final air risk class is identified as ARC-b. This indicates that the probability of encountering manned aircraft is low but not negligible, and that the airspace environment and operational context have been assessed accordingly under the AMC1 methodology.

Based on the combination of the final ground risk class of 3 and the final air risk class of ARC-b, the resulting specific assurance and integrity level for the operation is determined to be SAIL II. This SAIL level defines the set of operational safety objectives and the associated robustness requirements applicable to the operation.
chunk_summary: The operational risk classification results in a final ground risk class of 3 and a final air risk class of ARC-b. These combined assessments lead to a specific assurance and integrity level of SAIL II. This classification establishes the regulatory basis for the applicable safety objectives under AMC1 Article 11.

chunk_title: Operational Mitigations and Risk Buffers for PDRA-S01 Operations
chunk_text:
This section describes the operational mitigations applicable to the unmanned aircraft system operation under PDRA-S01, focusing on the definition and management of the operational volume, adjacent volume, ground risk buffer, and air risk buffer, in accordance with AMC1 Article 11. The assurance level for most mitigations is based on self-declaration, with integrity demonstrated by references to the relevant chapters or sections of the Operations Manual and assurance demonstrated through a declaration of compliance, unless otherwise specified.

The UAS operator is required to define the operational volume, the ground risk buffer, and the adjacent volume for the intended operation. This definition must include the flight geography and the contingency volume. For untethered unmanned aircraft, the contingency volume must extend at least 10 metres beyond the external limits of the flight geography. When determining the operational volume, the operator must take into account the position-keeping capabilities of the unmanned aircraft in four-dimensional space, including latitude, longitude, height, and time.

In particular, the accuracy of the navigation solution, the flight technical error of the unmanned aircraft, as well as flight path definition errors such as map errors, and system latencies must be considered and addressed when defining the operational volume. The size of the adjacent volume must also be clearly defined. The remote pilot is required to apply emergency procedures as soon as there is an indication that the unmanned aircraft may exceed the limits of the operational volume.

Operational mitigations further specify that no persons are to be overflown when spraying liquids or dropping substances. Infrastructure or facilities may only be overflown at the request of the entity responsible for that infrastructure or facility.

With respect to ground risk, the UAS operator must establish a ground risk buffer to protect third parties on the ground outside the operational volume. For untethered unmanned aircraft, the ground risk buffer must extend beyond the external limits of the contingency area by a minimum distance that depends on the maximum height above ground level and the maximum take-off mass of the unmanned aircraft. At a maximum height of 10 metres, the minimum ground risk buffer is 5 metres for an unmanned aircraft with a maximum take-off mass of up to 10 kilograms and 10 metres for a maximum take-off mass greater than 10 kilograms. At 30 metres, the buffer increases to 10 metres and 20 metres respectively. At 60 metres, the buffer is 15 metres for up to 10 kilograms and 30 metres for greater than 10 kilograms. At 90 metres, the buffer is 20 metres and 45 metres respectively. At 120 metres, the buffer is 25 metres for up to 10 kilograms and 60 metres for greater than 10 kilograms. At 150 metres, the buffer is 30 metres for up to 10 kilograms and 75 metres for greater than 10 kilograms. For tethered unmanned aircraft, the ground risk buffer is addressed through the conditions defined earlier for tethered operations.

For air risk, when the operation is performed above 120 metres and up to 150 metres, the UAS operator must establish an air risk buffer to protect third parties in the air outside the operational volume. If the air risk buffer lies within controlled airspace, the operation must be coordinated with the relevant air navigation service provider. The operator must also develop appropriate procedures to ensure that other airspace users are not jeopardised. This includes describing how remote pilots, and airspace observers if employed, are able to assess the height of the unmanned aircraft in relation to other airspace users.

Additional air risk mitigations require that the operational volume be located outside any geographical zone corresponding to a flight restriction zone of a protected aerodrome or any other restricted area, unless specific permission has been granted by the responsible authority. Prior to the flight, the UAS operator must assess the proximity of the planned operation to manned aircraft activity. A de-confliction scheme must be established to allow the remote pilot to take efficient decisions in the event of incoming traffic.

Regarding observers, airspace observers are indicated as not applicable, while the use of unmanned aircraft observers is referenced to another section identified as point 5.3.9(b).
chunk_summary: The operational mitigations define how the operational volume, contingency volume, adjacent volume, and risk buffers must be established and managed. Detailed minimum distances for ground risk buffers are provided based on aircraft mass and operating height, along with requirements for air risk buffers above 120 metres. These measures collectively ensure protection of third parties on the ground and in the air through structured planning, procedures, and declared compliance.

Additional air risk mitigations require that the operational volume be located outside any geographical zone corresponding to a flight restriction zone of a protected aerodrome or any other restricted area, unless specific permission has been granted by the responsible authority. Prior to the flight, the UAS operator must assess the proximity of the planned operation to manned aircraft activity. A de-confliction scheme must be established to allow the remote pilot to take efficient decisions in the event of incoming traffic.

Regarding observers, airspace observers are indicated as not applicable, while the use of unmanned aircraft observers is referenced to another section identified as point 5.3.9(b).

chunk_title: UAS Operator and UAS Operations Conditions under PDRA-S01
chunk_text:
This section defines the conditions applicable to the UAS operator and the conduct of UAS operations under PDRA-S01, with assurance generally based on declaration supported by data. The UAS operator is required to demonstrate sufficient confidence in the accuracy of information related to the height of the unmanned aircraft and in the means used to avert and avoid other airspace users and obstacles in the vicinity of the unmanned aircraft.

The UAS operator must develop an operations manual. For the template, reference is made to AMC1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e) and the complementary information provided in GM1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e). Within the operations manual, the operator must define and include the procedures used to determine the operational volume and the ground risk buffer for the intended operation, in line with points 3.1 to 3.6, as well as the adjacent volume.

The operator must also develop procedures to ensure that the operation is conducted safely and that all security requirements applicable to the area of operations are complied with during the intended operation. Measures must be developed to protect the UAS against unlawful interference and unauthorised access. In addition, procedures must be in place to ensure that all operations comply with Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data. In particular, the operator is required to carry out a data protection impact assessment when this is required by the data protection national authority of the Member State, with regard to the application of Article 35 of that Regulation.

Guidelines must be developed for remote pilots to plan UAS operations in a manner that minimises nuisance, including noise and other emissions-related nuisance, to people and animals. The operator must ensure the adequacy of contingency and emergency procedures and demonstrate this through dedicated flight tests, simulations whose representativeness is proven valid for the intended purpose with positive results, or any other means acceptable to the competent authority.

An effective emergency response plan suitable for the intended operation must be developed, with reference to GM1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e). Where a geo-awareness function is installed on the UAS, the operator must upload updated information into that function when required by the UAS geographical zone for the intended location of the operation.

Before starting the operation, the operator must ensure that the controlled ground area is in place, effective, and compliant with the minimum distances defined earlier, and that coordination with the appropriate authorities has been established when required. The operator must also ensure that, before the operation begins, all persons present in the controlled ground area have been informed of the risks of the operation, have been briefed or trained as appropriate on the safety precautions and measures established for their protection, and have explicitly agreed to participate in the operation.

For each flight, a remote pilot with adequate competency must be designated, along with any other personnel in charge of duties essential to the operation, if needed. When operations take place in controlled airspace, the operations manual must include a description of the method and means of communication with the authority or entity responsible for airspace management during the entire period of operation, as well as the identification of the personnel responsible for establishing that communication.

The operator must ensure that the UAS operation effectively uses and supports the efficient use of the radio spectrum in order to avoid harmful interference. Records related to UAS operations must be kept for a minimum of three years and maintained up to date, including records of any unusual technical or operational occurrences and other data required by the declaration or operational authorisation.

With regard to UAS maintenance, the operator must ensure that maintenance instructions defined by the operator are included in the operations manual and cover at least the UAS manufacturer’s instructions and requirements when applicable. Maintenance staff must follow these instructions when performing maintenance. Records of maintenance activities carried out on the UAS must be kept for a minimum of three years and kept up to date. The operator must also establish and maintain an up-to-date list of maintenance staff employed to carry out maintenance activities. Where certified equipment is used, the operator must comply with point UAS.SPEC.100.

For external services, the operator must ensure that the level of performance of any externally provided service that is necessary for the safety of the flight is adequate for the intended operation and must declare that this level of performance is adequately achieved. The operator must also define and allocate roles and responsibilities between itself and any external service providers, where applicable.
chunk_summary: These conditions set comprehensive organisational, operational, maintenance, and external service requirements for UAS operators under PDRA-S01. They focus on documented procedures, safety, security, privacy, emergency preparedness, personnel competence, recordkeeping, and coordination with authorities. Compliance is demonstrated primarily through declarations supported by evidence contained in the operations manual.

chunk_title: Conditions for Personnel in Charge of Duties Essential to the UAS Operation under PDRA-S01
chunk_text:
This section sets out the conditions applicable to personnel who perform duties essential to the unmanned aircraft system operation under PDRA-S01. The requirements cover general organisational responsibilities, the authority and obligations of the remote pilot, qualification and training requirements, and detailed duties before and during flight. Assurance is primarily based on self-declaration or declaration supported by data, with evidence maintained for inspection by the competent authority.

From a general perspective, the UAS operator is required to keep and maintain up-to-date records of all relevant qualifications and training courses completed by the remote pilot, other personnel essential to the UAS operation, and maintenance staff. These records must be retained for at least three years after the individuals cease to be employed by the organisation or change position within it. The remote pilot must be granted the authority to cancel or delay any or all flight operations whenever the safety of persons is jeopardised, property on the ground is jeopardised, other airspace users are in jeopardy, or there is a violation of the terms of the operational authorisation.

Specific conditions apply to the remote pilot. The remote pilot must not perform any duties under the influence of psychoactive substances or alcohol, nor when unfit to perform tasks due to injury, fatigue, medication, sickness, or other causes. The remote pilot must be familiar with the manufacturer’s instructions for the unmanned aircraft system and must ensure that the unmanned aircraft remains clear of clouds. The remote pilot is required to hold a certificate of remote pilot theoretical knowledge in accordance with Attachment A to Chapter I of Appendix 1 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation, issued either by the competent authority or by an entity designated by the competent authority of a Member State.

In addition, the remote pilot must hold an accreditation of completion of a practical-skills training course for this PDRA, in accordance with Attachment A to Chapter I of Appendix 1 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation. This accreditation must be issued either by an entity that has declared compliance with the requirements of Appendix 3 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation and is recognised by the competent authority of a Member State, or by a UAS operator that has been authorised by the competent authority of the Member State of registration to operate according to this PDRA, or that has declared compliance with STS-01 and with the requirements of Appendix 3 to the Annex to the UAS Regulation.

Where operations are conducted at heights between 120 metres and 150 metres, the remote pilot must undergo additional theoretical knowledge training. This training must address raising awareness of air risk and the existence of other airspace users, checking height determination and limitation devices, and using applicable procedures when a manned aircraft is detected. As an alternative to holding the theoretical knowledge certificate and the practical-skills accreditation, the operator may propose a dedicated training syllabus to the competent authority.

Before starting the UAS operation, the remote pilot must verify that the means to terminate the unmanned aircraft flight and the remote identification system are operational. The remote pilot must obtain updated information relevant to the intended operation concerning any geographical zones defined in accordance with Article 15 of the UAS Regulation. The remote pilot must also ensure that the unmanned aircraft is in a safe condition to complete the intended flight safely and, where applicable, verify that the direct remote identification is active and up to date.

During the flight, the remote pilot must keep the unmanned aircraft in visual line of sight and maintain a thorough visual scan of the surrounding airspace to avoid any risk of collision with manned aircraft. The flight must be discontinued if the operation poses a risk to other aircraft, people, animals, the environment, or property. For this purpose, the remote pilot may be assisted by a unmanned aircraft observer, provided that clear and effective communication is established between them. The remote pilot must apply the contingency procedures defined by the UAS operator for abnormal situations, including situations where there is an indication that the unmanned aircraft may exceed the limits of the flight geography. Emergency procedures must also be applied for emergencies, including triggering the means to terminate the flight when there is an indication that the unmanned aircraft may exceed the limits of the operational volume. The means to terminate the flight must be triggered at least 10 metres before the unmanned aircraft reaches the limits of the operational volume.

Additional in-flight requirements specify that, in the case of untethered unmanned aircraft, the remote pilot must keep the unmanned aircraft at a ground speed of less than 5 metres per second and must activate the direct remote identification system.
chunk_summary: These conditions define the responsibilities, authority, qualifications, and operational duties of personnel essential to UAS operations under PDRA-S01. They emphasise recordkeeping, pilot authority to halt unsafe operations, mandatory training and certification, and strict pre-flight and in-flight responsibilities. Together, they ensure that competent, well-prepared personnel maintain safety for people, property, and other airspace users.

chunk_title: Technical Conditions for UAS under PDRA-S01
chunk_text:
This section defines the technical conditions applicable to the unmanned aircraft system under PDRA-S01. As a primary option, the UAS operator should use a UAS that is marked as class C5 and that complies with the requirements of that class, as defined in Part 16 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945. In this case, the operator declares that the UAS is marked with a class C5 identification label, or declares that this requirement is not applicable.

As an alternative to using a class C5 UAS, the operator may use a UAS that complies with the requirements of Part 16 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945, with specific exceptions. Under this alternative, the UAS does not need to bear a class C3 or class C5 identification label, does not need to have a maximum take-off mass of less than 25 kg, and does not need to be exclusively powered by electricity, provided that the operator ensures that the environmental impact caused by the use of non-electric UAS is minimised. In addition, the UAS must include an information notice published by EASA that provides the applicable limitations and obligations required by the UAS Regulation. If the UAS is privately built, the manufacturer’s instructions must be included; however, information on its operation and maintenance, as well as on the training of the remote pilot, must be included in the operations manual.

It is noted that compliance with point (9) of Part 4 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945 may be achieved through the use of an add-on that complies with Part 6 of the Annex to that Regulation. Furthermore, if the unmanned aircraft does not bear a physical serial number compliant with standard ANSI/CTA 2063-A on small unmanned aerial systems serial numbers, and or does not have an integrated system of direct remote identification, compliance with point (9) of Part 4 may likewise be achieved by using an add-on that complies with Part 6 of the Annex.

Additional containment-related conditions apply when the adjacent area does not include a populated area or an assembly of people and when the adjacent airspace is classified as ARC-a or ARC-b. In such cases, point 5 of Part 16 of the Annex to Regulation (EU) 2019/945 may be replaced by basic containment conditions. These conditions require that no probable failure of the UAS or of any external system supporting the operation would lead to operation outside the operational volume, and that it is reasonably expected that a fatality will not occur due to any probable failure of the UAS or of any external system supporting the operation.

For these containment provisions, the operator may declare that basic containment applies and that a design and installation appraisal is available. This appraisal must cover at least the design and installation features, including independence, separation, and redundancy, as well as the particular risks relevant to the type of operation, such as hail, ice, snow, or electromagnetic interference. Alternatively, the operator may declare that enhanced containment applies and declare compliance with MoC Light-UAS.2511, with analysis and or test data and supporting evidence available, or declare that the UAS has a design verification report demonstrating compliance with the enhanced containment requirements.

Where the unmanned aircraft is designed to spray, additional technical conditions apply. The unmanned aircraft must be designed to avoid the accidental release of any substance, and it must provide the remote pilot with the means to immediately stop the spraying of liquids or the dropping of substances in case of an emergency.
chunk_summary: The technical conditions specify acceptable UAS configurations under PDRA-S01, either through use of a class C5 UAS or an alternative compliant with Part 16 of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. They address identification, remote identification solutions, containment requirements, and additional safeguards for spraying operations. Together, these conditions ensure that the UAS design and equipment support safe and compliant operations.

chunk_title: Scope of Predefined Risk Assessment PDRA-G02 Version 1.2
chunk_text:
This section presents the scope of the predefined risk assessment identified as PDRA-G02, version 1.2, issued in September 2023 under AMC3 Article 11 rules for conducting an operational risk assessment. It is associated with ED Decision 2023/012/R and applies within the framework of the UAS Regulation.

The PDRA-G02 results from applying the methodology described in AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation to unmanned aircraft system operations conducted in the specific category. The scope is defined by a set of main operational attributes that characterise the types of operations covered by this predefined risk assessment.

The unmanned aircraft involved must have maximum characteristic dimensions, such as wingspan, rotor diameter or area, or the maximum distance between rotor tips in the case of a multirotor, of up to 3 metres. These aircraft are also characterised by typical kinetic energies of up to 34 kilojoules.

The operations are conducted beyond visual line of sight of the remote pilot. They take place over sparsely populated areas, reducing exposure to third parties on the ground.

The airspace used for the operation is reserved or segregated specifically for the UAS operation. This airspace corresponds to an air risk that can be classified as ARC-a, indicating a very low probability of encountering manned aircraft.

Finally, the operations are conducted within the range of the direct command-and-control link. This link operates via radio line of sight and is maintained up to the height of the upper boundary of the reserved airspace.

The characterisation and conditions applicable to this predefined risk assessment are stated to be summarised in Table PDRA-G02.1, which follows this scope description.
chunk_summary: PDRA-G02 version 1.2 defines the scope for specific-category UAS operations conducted under AMC3 Article 11. It covers BVLOS operations with unmanned aircraft up to 3 metres in size and kinetic energies up to 34 kJ, flown over sparsely populated areas in reserved or segregated airspace classified as ARC-a. Operations must remain within direct radio line-of-sight command-and-control range.

chunk_title: PDRA-G02 Operational Characterisation and Conditions
chunk_text:
This content describes the operational characterisation, scope, and limitations applicable to PDRA-G02 under AMC3 Article 11, focusing on how unmanned aircraft system operations must be conducted and the conditions under which compliance is demonstrated.

With regard to the level of human intervention, autonomous operations are not permitted. The remote pilot must be able to maintain control of the unmanned aircraft at all times, except in the event of a loss of the command-and-control link. The remote pilot is required to operate only one unmanned aircraft at a time, must not operate the unmanned aircraft from a moving vehicle, and must not hand over control of the unmanned aircraft to another command unit. Compliance with these requirements is based on self-declaration, supported by references to the relevant sections of the operations manual.

Concerning the range of the unmanned aircraft, launch and recovery must take place within visual line of sight of the remote pilot when not operating from a safe prepared area. A safe prepared area is defined as a controlled ground area suitable for the safe launch and recovery of the unmanned aircraft. During flight, the operational range must remain within the coverage of the direct command-and-control link operating via radio line of sight, ensuring the safe conduct of the flight. These range limitations are subject to self-declaration, with references to the operations manual or a declaration of non-applicability where relevant.

Operations must be conducted over sparsely populated areas. Compliance requires a declaration supported by data, including a reference to the operations manual section that describes the procedures used to determine population density and an explanation of how population density data is identified.

The unmanned aircraft itself is subject to defined limitations. Its maximum characteristic dimension, such as wingspan, rotor diameter or area, or the maximum distance between rotor tips in the case of a multirotor, must not exceed 3 metres. In addition, the typical kinetic energy of the unmanned aircraft, as defined in paragraph 2.3.1(k) of AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation, must be up to 34 kilojoules. Compliance with these limitations is based on self-declaration with appropriate references to the operations manual.

The flight height of the operation is limited by the size of the reserved or segregated airspace in which the operation takes place. In addition to the vertical limit of the operational volume, an air risk buffer must be considered, as further addressed under the air risk conditions. These requirements are demonstrated through self-declaration with references to the operations manual.

Operations are restricted to airspace that is specifically reserved or segregated for unmanned aircraft system operations. This airspace corresponds to an air risk that can be classified as ARC-a. Compliance is based on self-declaration supported by references to the relevant sections of the operations manual.

Visibility requirements apply to take-off and landing phases conducted within the visual line of sight of the remote pilot. Visibility must be sufficient to ensure that no people are endangered during these phases, and the remote pilot must abort take-off or landing if people on the ground are in danger. Compliance is demonstrated through self-declaration or a declaration of non-applicability, with references to the operations manual where applicable.

Finally, additional operational limitations specify that the unmanned aircraft must not be used to drop material or to carry dangerous goods, except for dropping items in connection with agricultural, horticultural, or forestry activities, provided that such carriage does not contravene any other applicable regulations. Compliance with this condition is demonstrated through self-declaration with reference to the operations manual.
chunk_summary: These conditions define how PDRA-G02 operations must be conducted, covering human control, operational range, population exposure, aircraft limitations, airspace use, visibility, and prohibited uses. Compliance is primarily demonstrated through self-declaration supported by references to the operations manual and, where required, additional data. Together, they ensure that BVLOS operations under PDRA-G02 remain within clearly defined safety boundaries.

During flight, the operational range must remain within the coverage of the direct command-and-control link operating via radio line of sight, ensuring the safe conduct of the flight. These range limitations are subject to self-declaration, with references to the operations manual or a declaration of non-applicability where relevant.

Operations must be conducted over sparsely populated areas. Compliance requires a declaration supported by data, including a reference to the operations manual section that describes the procedures used to determine population density and an explanation of how population density data is identified.

The unmanned aircraft itself is subject to defined limitations. Its maximum characteristic dimension, such as wingspan, rotor diameter or area, or the maximum distance between rotor tips in the case of a multirotor, must not exceed 3 metres. In addition, the typical kinetic energy of the unmanned aircraft, as defined in paragraph 2.3.1(k) of AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation, must be up to 34 kilojoules. Compliance with these limitations is based on self-declaration with appropriate references to the operations manual.

The flight height of the operation is limited by the size of the reserved or segregated airspace in which the operation takes place. In addition to the vertical limit of the operational volume, an air risk buffer must be considered, as further addressed under the air risk conditions. These requirements are demonstrated through self-declaration with references to the operations manual.

Operations are restricted to airspace that is specifically reserved or segregated for unmanned aircraft system operations. This airspace corresponds to an air risk that can be classified as ARC-a. Compliance is based on self-declaration supported by references to the relevant sections of the operations manual.

Visibility requirements apply to take-off and landing phases conducted within the visual line of sight of the remote pilot. Visibility must be sufficient to ensure that no people are endangered during these phases, and the remote pilot must abort take-off or landing if people on the ground are in danger. Compliance is demonstrated through self-declaration or a declaration of non-applicability, with references to the operations manual where applicable.

Finally, additional operational limitations specify that the unmanned aircraft must not be used to drop material or to carry dangerous goods, except for dropping items in connection with agricultural, horticultural, or forestry activities, provided that such carriage does not contravene any other applicable regulations. Compliance with this condition is demonstrated through self-declaration with reference to the operations manual.

chunk_title: Operational Risk Classification for PDRA-G02 under AMC1 Article 11
chunk_text:
This section presents the operational risk classification of the unmanned aircraft system operation in accordance with the classification methodology defined in AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. The classification reflects the outcome of the ground and air risk assessments applicable to the PDRA-G02 operational context.

The final ground risk class for the operation is established as GRC 3. This indicates the assessed level of risk to people and property on the ground after considering the operational scenario, including the characteristics of the unmanned aircraft and the nature of the area overflown.

The final air risk class is identified as ARC-a. This classification corresponds to operations conducted in airspace that is reserved or segregated for the UAS operation, where the probability of encountering manned aircraft is very low.

Based on the combination of a final ground risk class of 3 and a final air risk class of ARC-a, the resulting specific assurance and integrity level for the operation is determined to be SAIL II. This SAIL level defines the applicable safety objectives and the required robustness of mitigations for operations conducted under PDRA-G02.

chunk_title: Operational Mitigations and PDRA Conditions for UAS Operations under EASA SORA
chunk_text:
This content describes operational mitigations related to the determination and management of the operational volume and associated ground and air risks for unmanned aircraft system operations, in line with AMC1 to Article 11 of Regulation (EU) 2019/947. Under operational volume considerations, the UAS operator is required to determine the operational volume by taking into account the position-keeping capabilities of the UAS in four-dimensional space, defined as latitude, longitude, height, and time. Particular attention must be given to the accuracy of the navigation solution, the flight technical error of the UAS, path definition errors such as map errors, and system latencies when defining this operational volume. The remote pilot is required to apply emergency procedures as soon as there is an indication that the unmanned aircraft may exceed the limits of the defined operational volume. For each of these conditions, the integrity section requests that a reference be included to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual, and the proof section indicates that compliance is declared through a self-declaration.

Ground risk mitigations are also detailed. The UAS operator must establish a ground risk buffer to protect third parties outside the operational volume. As a minimum criterion, the use of the ‘1:1 rule’ is specified, meaning that if the unmanned aircraft is planned to operate at a height of 150 metres, the ground risk buffer should be at least 150 metres. In addition, both the operational volume and the ground risk buffer must be entirely contained within a sparsely populated area. These ground risk measures are subject to self-declaration, with integrity demonstrated by referencing the appropriate section of the operations manual and proof provided through a declaration of compliance.

Further PDRA characterisation and conditions address the evaluation of the area of operations. The applicant is required to assess the area of operations, typically by means of an on-site inspection or appraisal, and must be able to justify a reduced density of people at risk within both the operational area and the ground risk buffer. In relation to air risk, the operational volume, including the air risk buffer where applicable, must be entirely contained within reserved or segregated airspace. As with the other conditions, the integrity requirement calls for a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual, and proof is provided by a declaration of compliance.
chunk_summary: The text outlines mandatory operational mitigations for defining operational volume and managing ground and air risks in UAS operations under EASA SORA. It specifies requirements for position-keeping accuracy, emergency procedures, ground risk buffers, population density considerations, and airspace containment. Compliance with these conditions is demonstrated through self-declaration, supported by references to the operations manual.

chunk_title: PDRA Characterisation and Conditions for UAS Operators, Maintenance, and External Services
chunk_text:
The content describes conditions applicable to UAS operators and UAS operations under a predefined risk assessment framework. It specifies that the UAS operator should develop an operations manual, referred to as the OM, in line with AMC1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e) and complementary guidance in GM1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e). The operator is expected to declare compliance and confirm that supporting evidence is included in the OM. Procedures must be developed to ensure that security requirements applicable to the area of operations are complied with during the intended operation, with references to the relevant chapters or sections of the OM. Measures must also be developed to protect the UAS against unlawful interference and unauthorised access, again with references to the OM.

The operator must develop procedures ensuring that all operations comply with Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data. This includes carrying out a data protection impact assessment when required by the data protection national authority of the Member State in accordance with Article 35 of that Regulation. The operator should develop guidelines for remote pilots to plan UAS operations in a manner that minimises nuisance, including noise and other emissions-related nuisance, to people and animals. An emergency response plan, referred to as an ERP, must be developed in accordance with the conditions for a medium level of robustness, with reference to AMC3 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e), and the operator must describe how this condition is met and declare that the ERP is available to the competent authority for review.

Operational procedures must be validated in accordance with the conditions for a medium level of robustness, including those described in AMC2 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e). The operator must ensure the adequacy of contingency and emergency procedures and prove this through dedicated flight tests, simulations with proven representativeness and positive results, or any other means acceptable to the competent authority. The operator must have a policy defining how the remote pilot and any other personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation declare themselves fit to operate before conducting any operation.

For each flight, a remote pilot with adequate competency must be designated, along with any other personnel essential to the operation if needed. The operator must ensure effective use and support of efficient radio spectrum use in order to avoid harmful interference. Records related to UAS operations, including unusual technical or operational occurrences, must be kept for a minimum of three years and maintained up to date, with recordkeeping data made available to the competent authority. As part of the procedures in the operations manual, the operator must include a description of the method and means of communication with the authority or entity responsible for the management of the airspace during the entire period of reserved or segregated airspace being active, as mandated by the authorisation. A note specifies that the communication method should be published in the NOTAM activating the reserved airspace to allow coordination with manned aircraft, and the personnel responsible for establishing that communication must be identified.

The text also addresses UAS maintenance requirements. The UAS operator should ensure that maintenance instructions defined by the operator are included in the operations manual and cover at least the UAS manufacturer’s instructions and requirements when applicable. Maintenance staff must follow these instructions when performing maintenance. Records of maintenance activities conducted on the UAS must be kept for a minimum of three years and maintained up to date. The operator must establish and keep an up-to-date list of maintenance staff employed to carry out maintenance activities. If the UAS uses certified equipment, the operator must comply with point UAS.SPEC.100, with a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual or an indication of not applicable.

Finally, the section on external services states that the UAS operator should ensure that the level of performance for any externally provided service necessary for the safety of the flight is adequate for the intended operation and declare that this level of performance is adequately achieved. The operator should also define and allocate the roles and responsibilities between the UAS operator and any external service providers, if applicable. Across these conditions, the method of proof is primarily self-declaration or declaration supported by data, with explanations of integrity and statements that evidence is available to the competent authority for review.
chunk_summary: The text sets out detailed conditions that UAS operators must meet under a PDRA framework, covering operations, security, data protection, emergency planning, personnel competence, and recordkeeping. It also defines maintenance obligations, including manuals, staff responsibilities, and retention of maintenance records. In addition, it addresses the management of external services and the need for clear allocation of responsibilities, with compliance demonstrated mainly through declarations supported by documented evidence.

chunk_title: Conditions for Personnel in Charge of Duties Essential to the UAS Operation
chunk_text:
This content sets out the conditions applicable to personnel who are responsible for duties essential to an unmanned aircraft system operation, as defined within a predefined risk assessment framework. The general requirement states that the UAS operator must ensure that all personnel performing essential duties are provided with competency-based theoretical and practical training that is specific to their assigned responsibilities. This training consists of applicable theoretical elements derived from AMC1 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and practical elements derived from AMC2 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and UAS.SPEC.050(1)(e). The condition requires a description of how this training requirement is met, while proof is provided through a declaration of compliance. Evidence of training must be available for inspection at the request of the competent authority or its authorised representative, and the training programme must be documented.

The UAS operator is also required to keep and maintain up-to-date records of all relevant qualifications and training courses completed by the remote pilot, other personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation, and maintenance staff. These records must be retained for at least three years after the individuals have ceased to be employed by the organisation or have changed position within it. The condition requires a description of how record keeping is ensured, with proof again provided through a declaration of compliance and availability of records for inspection by the competent authority.

Specific conditions apply to the remote pilot. The remote pilot must have the authority to cancel or delay any or all flight operations when the safety of persons is jeopardised, when property on the ground is jeopardised, when other airspace users are jeopardised, or when there is a violation of the terms of the operational authorisation. The remote pilot must also not perform duties while under the influence of psychoactive substances or alcohol, or when unfit due to injury, fatigue, medication, sickness, or other causes. In addition, the remote pilot must be familiar with the manufacturer’s instructions for the UAS, obtain updated information relevant to the intended operation concerning any geographical zones defined in accordance with Article 15, and ensure that the UAS is in a safe condition to complete the intended flight safely. Where applicable, the remote pilot must also check that direct remote identification is active and up to date. For each of these conditions, integrity is demonstrated by including a reference to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual, and proof is provided through a declaration of compliance.

Where multi-crew cooperation is required, the UAS operator must designate a remote pilot-in-command responsible for each flight. The operator must also include procedures to ensure coordination between remote crew members through robust and effective communication channels. These procedures must cover, as a minimum, the assignment of tasks to the remote crew members and the establishment of step-by-step communication. The training of the remote crew must cover multi-crew cooperation. For these conditions, integrity is demonstrated by reference to the relevant section of the operations manual or indicated as not applicable, and proof is provided through a declaration of compliance or noted as not applicable.

For maintenance staff, any staff member authorised by the UAS operator to perform maintenance activities must have been adequately trained in the documented maintenance procedures. Integrity is demonstrated by reference to the relevant section of the operations manual, and proof consists of a declaration of compliance supported by data, with evidence of training available at the request of the competent authority.

Finally, personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation must declare that they are fit to operate before conducting any operation. This declaration must be based on a policy defined by the UAS operator, with integrity shown by reference to the relevant section of the operations manual and proof provided through a declaration of compliance.
chunk_summary: The text defines comprehensive requirements for training, authority, fitness, coordination, and record keeping for personnel essential to UAS operations. It specifies obligations for remote pilots, multi-crew operations, maintenance staff, and other essential personnel. Compliance is primarily demonstrated through self-declaration, supported by references to the operations manual and the availability of evidence for inspection by the competent authority.

chunk_title: Technical Conditions for UAS Equipment, Interfaces, Communications, Containment, and Identification
chunk_text:
This content defines the technical conditions applicable to an unmanned aircraft system under a predefined risk assessment. The general technical requirement states that the UAS must be equipped with means to monitor the critical parameters necessary for safe flight. These parameters include the unmanned aircraft’s position, height or altitude, ground speed or airspeed, attitude, and trajectory. The system must also provide monitoring of the UAS energy status, such as fuel level or battery charge. In addition, the status of critical functions and systems must be monitored. As a minimum, for services based on radio-frequency signals such as the command-and-control link and GNSS, the system must be capable of monitoring adequate performance and triggering an alert when performance becomes too low. Compliance with these monitoring requirements is demonstrated by including references to the relevant sections of the operations manual and by a declaration of compliance.

Human–machine interface requirements specify that UAS information and control interfaces must be clearly and succinctly presented. The interfaces must not confuse personnel, cause unreasonable fatigue, or contribute to disturbances that could adversely affect the safety of the operation. The UAS operator is required to conduct an evaluation that considers and addresses human factors in order to determine whether the human–machine interface is appropriate for the intended operation. Compliance is shown through references to the operations manual or by describing how this condition is met, supported by a declaration of compliance.

Requirements for command-and-control links and communication state that the UAS must comply with the applicable requirements for radio equipment and the use of the radio-frequency spectrum. Protection mechanisms against interference must be used, particularly when unlicensed bands such as ISM bands are employed for the command-and-control link. Examples of such mechanisms include frequency-hopping spread spectrum, direct-sequence spread spectrum, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing technologies, or frequency deconfliction by procedure. The command-and-control link must also be protected against unauthorised access to the command-and-control functions. In the event of loss of the command-and-control link, the UAS must have a reliable and predictable method to recover the link or to terminate the flight in a manner that reduces any undesirable effects on third parties in the air or on the ground. The operator must ensure that reliable and continuous means of two-way communication are available for the purpose identified elsewhere in the conditions. These requirements are addressed through references to the operations manual and declarations of compliance.

Containment provisions require that, to ensure safe recovery from a technical issue involving the UAS or any external system supporting the operation, the UAS complies with basic containment conditions. It must be ensured that no probable failure of the UAS or of any supporting external system would lead to operation outside the operational volume. It must also be reasonably expected that a fatality will not occur due to any probable failure of the UAS or of any external supporting system. The term ‘probable’ is defined qualitatively as anticipated to occur one or more times during the entire system or operational life of an item. Compliance is demonstrated by describing how these conditions are met and by providing a declaration supported by data, such as a design and installation appraisal covering design and installation features including independence, separation, and redundancy, as well as particular risks such as hail, ice, snow, or electromagnetic interference that are relevant to the type of operation.

Enhanced containment conditions apply when the adjacent area includes an assembly of people or when the adjacent airspace is classified as ARC-d in accordance with SORA. In such cases, the UAS must be designed to standards considered adequate by the competent authority or in accordance with an acceptable means of compliance. The probability of the unmanned aircraft leaving the operational volume must be less than 10 to the power of minus four per flight hour, and no single failure of the UAS or of any external system supporting the operation should lead to operation outside the ground risk buffer. Failures are defined as occurrences that affect the operation of a component, part, or element such that it can no longer function as intended, while errors are not considered failures. Some structural or mechanical failures may be excluded if it can be shown that the parts were designed according to aviation industry best practices. Software and airborne electronic hardware whose development errors could directly lead to operations outside the ground risk buffer must be developed according to an industry standard or methodology recognised as adequate by EASA. Notes clarify that the additional safety conditions cover both integrity and assurance levels and do not necessarily imply a systematic need to develop software and airborne electronic hardware to a recognised industry standard if design features systematically prevent exit from the ground risk buffer.

Remote identification requirements state that the UAS must have a unique serial number compliant with ANSI/CTA-2063-A-2019, Small Unmanned Aerial Systems Serial Numbers, in accordance with Article 40(4) of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. The UAS must also be equipped with a remote identification system in accordance with Article 40(5) of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. Compliance with these requirements is demonstrated by describing how the conditions are met and by a declaration of compliance.

Finally, lighting requirements specify that if the UAS is operated at night, it must be equipped with at least one green flashing light in accordance with point UAS.SPEC.050(1)(l)(i) of the UAS Regulation. Compliance is shown by describing how the condition is met or by indicating that it is not applicable, supported by a declaration of compliance or a statement of not applicable.
chunk_summary: The text outlines comprehensive technical conditions for UAS monitoring, interfaces, communications, containment, identification, and lighting. It specifies requirements for safe flight parameter monitoring, human–machine interface suitability, protected and reliable command-and-control links, and both basic and enhanced containment measures. Compliance is primarily demonstrated through references to the operations manual, descriptive explanations where required, and declarations of compliance supported by data when applicable.

The term ‘probable’ is defined qualitatively as anticipated to occur one or more times during the entire system or operational life of an item. Compliance is demonstrated by describing how these conditions are met and by providing a declaration supported by data, such as a design and installation appraisal covering design and installation features including independence, separation, and redundancy, as well as particular risks such as hail, ice, snow, or electromagnetic interference that are relevant to the type of operation.

Enhanced containment conditions apply when the adjacent area includes an assembly of people or when the adjacent airspace is classified as ARC-d in accordance with SORA. In such cases, the UAS must be designed to standards considered adequate by the competent authority or in accordance with an acceptable means of compliance. The probability of the unmanned aircraft leaving the operational volume must be less than 10 to the power of minus four per flight hour, and no single failure of the UAS or of any external system supporting the operation should lead to operation outside the ground risk buffer. Failures are defined as occurrences that affect the operation of a component, part, or element such that it can no longer function as intended, while errors are not considered failures. Some structural or mechanical failures may be excluded if it can be shown that the parts were designed according to aviation industry best practices. Software and airborne electronic hardware whose development errors could directly lead to operations outside the ground risk buffer must be developed according to an industry standard or methodology recognised as adequate by EASA. Notes clarify that the additional safety conditions cover both integrity and assurance levels and do not necessarily imply a systematic need to develop software and airborne electronic hardware to a recognised industry standard if design features systematically prevent exit from the ground risk buffer.

Remote identification requirements state that the UAS must have a unique serial number compliant with ANSI/CTA-2063-A-2019, Small Unmanned Aerial Systems Serial Numbers, in accordance with Article 40(4) of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. The UAS must also be equipped with a remote identification system in accordance with Article 40(5) of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. Compliance with these requirements is demonstrated by describing how the conditions are met and by a declaration of compliance.

Finally, lighting requirements specify that if the UAS is operated at night, it must be equipped with at least one green flashing light in accordance with point UAS.SPEC.050(1)(l)(i) of the UAS Regulation. Compliance is shown by describing how the condition is met or by indicating that it is not applicable, supported by a declaration of compliance or a statement of not applicable.

chunk_title: Predefined Risk Assessment PDRA-G01 Version 1.3 – Scope and Applicability
chunk_text:
This text presents the scope of the Predefined Risk Assessment identified as PDRA-G01, Version 1.3, issued in the September 2023 edition. The document explains that this predefined risk assessment is the result of applying the methodology described in AMC1 Article 11 of the UAS Regulation to unmanned aircraft system operations that are conducted within the ‘specific’ category.

The scope defines the types of operations that fall under this PDRA. It applies to operations using unmanned aircraft with maximum characteristic dimensions of up to 3 metres. Examples of characteristic dimensions are given, including wingspan, rotor diameter or rotor area, or the maximum distance between rotors in the case of a multirotor aircraft. These aircraft are further limited to a typical kinetic energy of up to 34 kilojoules.

The operations covered by this PDRA are conducted beyond visual line of sight of the remote pilot, with visual air risk mitigation in place. They are limited to operations carried out over sparsely populated areas. The scope also specifies an altitude limitation, stating that the operation must be conducted at less than 150 metres, or 500 feet, above the surface overflown, unless another altitude reference is defined by the relevant Member State. Finally, the operations must take place in uncontrolled airspace.
chunk_summary: PDRA-G01 Version 1.3 defines the scope of specific-category UAS operations eligible for a predefined risk assessment. It applies to small UAS with limited kinetic energy, operating BVLOS with visual air risk mitigation over sparsely populated areas. The operations are restricted to low altitude and uncontrolled airspace.

chunk_title: Operational Characterisation, Scope, and Limitations for PDRA-G01 Operations
chunk_text:
This content describes the operational characterisation, scope, and limitations applicable to UAS operations conducted under a predefined risk assessment. The level of human intervention is defined by the requirement that no autonomous operations are allowed. The remote pilot must have the ability to maintain control of the unmanned aircraft at all times, except in the event of a loss of the command-and-control link. In addition, the remote pilot is required to operate only one unmanned aircraft at a time. Further limitations specify that the remote pilot must not operate the unmanned aircraft from a moving vehicle and must not hand control of the unmanned aircraft over to another command unit. Compliance with these conditions is demonstrated through references to the relevant sections of the operations manual and by declarations of compliance.

Operational range limitations apply to both launch and recovery and to flight operations. Launch and recovery must take place at visual line-of-sight distance from the remote pilot if operations are not conducted from a safe prepared area. A safe prepared area is defined as a controlled ground area that is suitable for the safe launch and recovery of the unmanned aircraft. During flight, if no air observers are employed, the unmanned aircraft must not be operated further than one kilometre, or another distance defined by the competent authority, from the remote pilot. A note specifies that the remote pilot’s workload must allow continuous visual scanning of the airspace. If air observers are employed, the range is not limited provided that the unmanned aircraft is not operated further than one kilometre, unless otherwise defined by the competent authority, from the air observer who is nearest to the unmanned aircraft. These conditions are subject to self-declaration with references to the operations manual or indication of not applicable, as appropriate.

Requirements concerning overflown areas state that UAS operations must be conducted over sparsely populated areas. The method of proof requires a declaration supported by data, including a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual where procedures for determining population density are described. Proof also requires a declaration of compliance and a description of how population density data is identified.

Unmanned aircraft limitations include a maximum characteristic dimension of three metres. Examples of characteristic dimensions include wingspan, rotor diameter or rotor area, or the maximum distance between rotors in the case of a multirotor aircraft. The typical kinetic energy of the unmanned aircraft must be up to 34 kilojoules, as defined in paragraph 2.3.1(k) of AMC1 to Article 11 of the UAS Regulation. Compliance with these limitations is demonstrated by references to the operations manual and declarations of compliance.

Flight height limitations require that the maximum height of the operational volume must not exceed 150 metres, or 500 feet, above the overflown area, or any other altitude reference defined by the Member State. A note clarifies that, in addition to the vertical limit of the operational volume, an air risk buffer must be considered, as addressed under air risk requirements. These conditions are subject to self-declaration with references to the operations manual and declarations of compliance.

Airspace requirements specify that the unmanned aircraft must be operated either in uncontrolled airspace corresponding to an air risk that can be classified as ARC-b, in a segregated area corresponding to an air risk that can be classified as ARC-a, or as otherwise established by the Member States in accordance with Article 15, with an associated air risk that can be classified as not higher than ARC-b. Each of these options requires a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual and a declaration of compliance.

Visibility requirements state that the unmanned aircraft must be operated in an area where flight visibility is greater than five kilometres. A note refers to GM1 UAS.STS-02.020(3). Compliance is demonstrated through a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual and a declaration of compliance.

Additional operational limitations specify that the unmanned aircraft must not be used to drop material or to carry dangerous goods. An exception is provided for dropping items in connection with agricultural, horticultural, or forestry activities, where the carriage of such items does not contravene any other applicable regulations. Compliance with this condition is demonstrated through a reference to the relevant section of the operations manual and a declaration of compliance.
chunk_summary: The text defines detailed operational limitations and scope conditions for UAS operations under a predefined risk assessment. It covers human control requirements, range and altitude limits, population density constraints, aircraft size and energy limits, airspace and visibility conditions, and restrictions on payload use. Compliance is demonstrated primarily through self-declaration, supported by references to the operations manual and, where required, additional data.
