chunk_title: PDRA Characterisation and Conditions – Operational, Ground, Air Risk, and Observer Mitigations
chunk_text:
The content describes a set of predefined risk assessment conditions related to unmanned aircraft system operations, focusing on operational mitigations, ground risk, air risk, and the use of observers. Under operational volume considerations, the applicant is required to determine the operational volume by accounting for the position-keeping capabilities of the unmanned aircraft system in four-dimensional space, including latitude, longitude, height, and time. This determination must consider the accuracy of the navigation solution, the flight technical error of the unmanned aircraft system, the flight path definition error such as map errors, and any latencies. The remote pilot is required to apply emergency procedures immediately when there is an indication that the unmanned aircraft may exceed the limits of the defined operational volume. For each of these operational mitigation points, the integrity requirement requests the inclusion of a reference to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual, and the proof is provided through a declaration of compliance.

Ground risk mitigation requirements specify that the unmanned aircraft system operator must establish a ground risk buffer to protect third parties on the ground outside the operational volume. The minimum criterion for this buffer is the use of the one-to-one rule, meaning that if the unmanned aircraft is planned to operate at a height of 150 metres, the ground risk buffer should be at least 150 metres. The operational volume together with the ground risk buffer must be entirely contained within a sparsely populated area. The applicant is also expected to evaluate the area of operations, typically through an on-site inspection or appraisal, and to be able to justify a lower density of people at risk within both the operational area and the ground risk buffer. These ground risk conditions are supported by self-declaration, require references to the operations manual in the integrity column, and are demonstrated through a declaration of compliance.

Air risk mitigation conditions require the unmanned aircraft system operator to establish an air risk buffer to protect third parties in the air outside the operational volume. This air risk buffer must be contained within airspace that meets defined conditions and must be over sparsely populated areas. If the operation is limited to a height below 120 metres, no additional vertical air risk buffer is required. If the height of the operation is above 120 metres and up to 150 metres, supporting evidence must be included in the operations manual, along with justification that the appropriate air risk buffer is documented. The operational volume must also be outside any geographical zone corresponding to a flight restriction zone unless the operator has been granted appropriate permission. Prior to flight, the remote pilot must assess the proximity of the planned operation to manned aircraft activity. Integrity requirements again request references to the relevant sections of the operations manual, and proof is generally provided by a declaration of compliance, with additional supporting evidence where height exceeds 120 metres.

Additional conditions apply when operations are performed above 120 metres and up to 150 metres. In such cases, the unmanned aircraft system operator is required to develop appropriate procedures to ensure that other airspace users are not jeopardised. The integrity requirement asks for a reference to the operations manual and a description of how remote pilots and, if employed, airspace observers are able to assess the height of the unmanned aircraft compared to other airspace users. Proof consists of a declaration of compliance supported by evidence included in the operations manual.

Observer-related provisions state that if the unmanned aircraft system operator decides to employ one or more airspace observers, the remote pilot may operate the unmanned aircraft up to the distance specified elsewhere. The operator must ensure the correct placement and appropriate number of observers along the intended flight path. Before each flight, the operator must verify that the visibility and planned distance of the observers are within acceptable limits defined in the operations manual, that there are no potential terrain obstructions for each observer, that there are no gaps between the zones covered by each observer, and that communication with each observer is established and effective. If means are used by observers to determine the position of the unmanned aircraft, those means must be functioning and effective. A note clarifies that instead of an airspace observer, the remote pilot may perform the visual scan of the airspace, provided that workload allows. For these observer-related conditions, integrity requires a reference to the operations manual or an indication of not applicable, and proof is given by a declaration of compliance or not applicable.
chunk_summary: The document sets out predefined operational, ground, air risk, and observer-related conditions for unmanned aircraft system operations under a PDRA framework. It defines how operational volumes and risk buffers must be established, justified, and contained within sparsely populated areas. Compliance is primarily demonstrated through self-declaration, supported by references and evidence in the operations manual where required.

chunk_title: UAS Operator, Operations, Maintenance, and External Services Conditions under PDRA
chunk_text:
The content describes the conditions that a UAS operator must meet regarding operations, personnel, maintenance, and external services within a predefined risk assessment framework. The UAS operator is required to develop and maintain an operations manual that complies with AMC1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e) and GM1 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e), and to explain how this requirement is met. Procedures must be established to ensure compliance with security requirements applicable to the area of operations, protection of the UAS against unlawful interference and unauthorised access, and adherence to Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on data protection, including the execution of a data protection impact assessment when required by the national data protection authority.

The operator must also define guidelines for remote pilots to plan operations in a way that minimises nuisance, including noise and other emissions-related disturbance to people and animals. An emergency response plan must be developed in accordance with the conditions for a medium level of robustness, with reference to AMC3 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e), and the operator must describe how this plan is implemented. Operational procedures must be validated against the same medium robustness requirements referenced in AMC2 UAS.SPEC.030(3)(e). The adequacy of contingency and emergency procedures must be ensured and demonstrated through dedicated flight tests, simulations with proven representativeness and positive results, or other means acceptable to the competent authority.

The UAS operator is further required to have a policy ensuring that remote pilots and other essential personnel declare themselves fit to operate before any flight. For each flight, a remote pilot with adequate competency must be designated, along with any other personnel responsible for duties essential to the operation. The operation must make effective and efficient use of the radio spectrum to avoid harmful interference. Records of UAS operations, including unusual technical or operational occurrences, must be maintained for a minimum of three years and kept up to date as required by the declaration or operational authorisation.

With regard to maintenance, the operator must ensure that UAS maintenance instructions are included in the operations manual and cover at least the manufacturer’s instructions and requirements when applicable. Maintenance staff must follow these instructions when performing maintenance. Records of maintenance activities conducted on the UAS must be kept for a minimum of three years, and an up-to-date list of maintenance staff employed by the operator must be established and maintained. If the UAS uses certified equipment, compliance with UAS.SPEC.100 is required, with reference to the relevant section of the operations manual or marked as not applicable where appropriate.

For external services, the UAS operator must ensure that the level of performance of any externally provided service necessary for flight safety is adequate for the intended operation, and must declare that this performance level is adequately achieved. In addition, the operator must define and allocate roles and responsibilities between the UAS operator and any external service providers, where applicable. For most conditions, proof consists of a declaration of compliance, often accompanied by confirmation that supporting evidence or descriptions are available to the competent authority for review.
chunk_summary: The text outlines comprehensive operational, organisational, maintenance, and external service requirements for UAS operators under a predefined risk assessment. It emphasises documented procedures, validated operations, emergency preparedness, personnel competency, data protection, and recordkeeping. Compliance is primarily demonstrated through declarations supported by evidence available for competent authority review.

chunk_title: Conditions for Personnel in Charge of Duties Essential to UAS Operations under PDRA
chunk_text:
The content describes the conditions applicable to personnel who are responsible for duties essential to unmanned aircraft system operations, as defined within a predefined risk assessment framework. It begins by stating that the UAS operator must ensure that all such personnel receive competency-based theoretical and practical training that is specific to their assigned duties. This training includes applicable theoretical elements derived from AMC1 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and practical elements from AMC2 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and UAS.SPEC.050(1)(e). For non-remote pilots, additional training elements are also derived from AMC3 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d). Compliance is declared, with evidence of training available for inspection upon request by the competent authority, and the training programme documented in the operations manual.

The operator is also required to keep and maintain up-to-date records of all relevant qualifications and training courses completed by the remote pilot, other personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation, and maintenance staff. These records must be retained for at least three years after the individuals cease to be employed by the organisation or change position within it. Compliance is declared, and record-keeping data must be available for inspection by the competent authority upon request.

The conditions further specify the responsibilities of the remote pilot. The remote pilot must have the authority to cancel or delay any or all flight operations when the safety of persons is jeopardised, when property on the ground is jeopardised, when other airspace users are jeopardised, or when there is a violation of the terms of the operational authorisation. For each of these circumstances, a reference to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual is requested, and compliance is declared.

If air observers are employed, the remote pilot must ensure that the necessary number of observers is available and correctly positioned, and that communication with them can be adequately established. The remote pilot is also required to meet several personal and operational conditions, including not performing duties under the influence of psychoactive substances or alcohol, or when unfit due to injury, fatigue, medication, sickness, or other causes. The remote pilot must be familiar with the manufacturer’s instructions for the UAS, ensure that the unmanned aircraft remains clear of clouds, perform an unaided visual scan of the airspace to avoid potential collision hazards, obtain updated information relevant to the intended operation regarding geographical zones defined in accordance with Article 15 of the UAS Regulation, and ensure that the UAS is in a safe condition to complete the intended flight, including checking that direct remote identification is active and up to date if applicable. For all these conditions, references to the relevant sections of the operations manual are requested and compliance is declared.

Where multi-crew cooperation is required, the UAS operator must designate a remote pilot-in-command responsible for each flight. Procedures must be included to ensure coordination between remote crew members through robust and effective communication channels. As a minimum, these procedures must cover the assignment of tasks to remote crew members and the establishment of step-by-step communication. The operator must also ensure that the training of the remote crew covers multi-crew cooperation. For these conditions, references to the operations manual are requested, and compliance is declared or marked as not applicable where appropriate.

Maintenance staff are also addressed. Any maintenance staff member authorised by the UAS operator to perform maintenance activities must have been adequately trained in the documented maintenance procedures. Compliance is declared, supporting evidence is included in the operations manual, and evidence of training must be available to the competent authority upon request.

Finally, personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation are required to declare that they are fit to operate before conducting any operation, based on the policy defined by the UAS operator. A reference to the relevant section of the operations manual is requested, and compliance is declared.

It defines responsibilities for remote pilots, multi-crew operations, air observers, and maintenance staff, with strong emphasis on safety authority and operational readiness. Compliance is largely demonstrated through self-declaration, supported by documented procedures and evidence held in the operations manual.

The content describes the conditions applicable to personnel who are responsible for duties essential to unmanned aircraft system operations, as defined within a predefined risk assessment framework. It begins by stating that the UAS operator must ensure that all such personnel receive competency-based theoretical and practical training that is specific to their assigned duties. This training includes applicable theoretical elements derived from AMC1 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and practical elements from AMC2 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d) and UAS.SPEC.050(1)(e). For non-remote pilots, additional training elements are also derived from AMC3 UAS.SPEC.050(1)(d). Compliance is declared, with evidence of training available for inspection upon request by the competent authority, and the training programme documented in the operations manual.

The operator is also required to keep and maintain up-to-date records of all relevant qualifications and training courses completed by the remote pilot, other personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation, and maintenance staff. These records must be retained for at least three years after the individuals cease to be employed by the organisation or change position within it. Compliance is declared, and record-keeping data must be available for inspection by the competent authority upon request.

The conditions further specify the responsibilities of the remote pilot. The remote pilot must have the authority to cancel or delay any or all flight operations when the safety of persons is jeopardised, when property on the ground is jeopardised, when other airspace users are jeopardised, or when there is a violation of the terms of the operational authorisation. For each of these circumstances, a reference to the relevant chapter or section of the operations manual is requested, and compliance is declared.

If air observers are employed, the remote pilot must ensure that the necessary number of observers is available and correctly positioned, and that communication with them can be adequately established. The remote pilot is also required to meet several personal and operational conditions, including not performing duties under the influence of psychoactive substances or alcohol, or when unfit due to injury, fatigue, medication, sickness, or other causes. The remote pilot must be familiar with the manufacturer’s instructions for the UAS, ensure that the unmanned aircraft remains clear of clouds, perform an unaided visual scan of the airspace to avoid potential collision hazards, obtain updated information relevant to the intended operation regarding geographical zones defined in accordance with Article 15 of the UAS Regulation, and ensure that the UAS is in a safe condition to complete the intended flight, including checking that direct remote identification is active and up to date if applicable. For all these conditions, references to the relevant sections of the operations manual are requested and compliance is declared.

Where multi-crew cooperation is required, the UAS operator must designate a remote pilot-in-command responsible for each flight. Procedures must be included to ensure coordination between remote crew members through robust and effective communication channels. As a minimum, these procedures must cover the assignment of tasks to remote crew members and the establishment of step-by-step communication. The operator must also ensure that the training of the remote crew covers multi-crew cooperation. For these conditions, references to the operations manual are requested, and compliance is declared or marked as not applicable where appropriate.

Maintenance staff are also addressed. Any maintenance staff member authorised by the UAS operator to perform maintenance activities must have been adequately trained in the documented maintenance procedures. Compliance is declared, supporting evidence is included in the operations manual, and evidence of training must be available to the competent authority upon request.

Finally, personnel in charge of duties essential to the UAS operation are required to declare that they are fit to operate before conducting any operation, based on the policy defined by the UAS operator. A reference to the relevant section of the operations manual is requested, and compliance is declared.

chunk_title: PDRA-G01 Main Technical Limitations, Conditions, and Compliance Provisions
chunk_text:
This content sets out the technical conditions, limitations, and compliance expectations applicable to PDRA-G01 operations for unmanned aircraft systems (UAS). It begins with technical conditions requiring the UAS to be equipped with monitoring capabilities for critical flight parameters. These include the unmanned aircraft position, height or altitude, ground speed or airspeed, attitude, and trajectory, as well as the UAS energy status such as fuel or battery charge. The system must also provide visibility of the status of critical functions and systems, including services based on radio-frequency signals such as the command-and-control link and GNSS, with alerts triggered when performance becomes too low. In addition, the UAS must be capable of descending safely from its operating altitude to a defined safe altitude within less than one minute, or at a descent rate of at least 2.5 m/s (500 feet per minute).

Human–machine interface requirements specify that UAS information and control interfaces must be clearly and succinctly presented, must not confuse the operator, must not cause unreasonable fatigue, and must not disturb personnel responsible for duties essential to safe operation. Where electronic means are used to support air observers in maintaining awareness of the UAS position, the interface must be easy to understand and must not degrade the observers’ ability to perform unaided visual scanning of the airspace for collision hazards or to maintain effective communication with the remote pilot at all times. The UAS operator is also required to conduct a human factors evaluation to determine whether the interface is appropriate for the intended operation.

Conditions related to command-and-control links and communications require compliance with applicable radio equipment and radio-frequency spectrum requirements. Protection mechanisms against interference must be used, particularly when unlicensed bands such as ISM bands are employed, using techniques such as frequency hopping, direct sequence spread spectrum, orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing, or procedural frequency deconfliction. The command-and-control link must be protected against unauthorised access, and in the event of a loss of the link, the UAS must have a reliable and predictable method to recover the link or to terminate the flight in a way that reduces undesirable effects on third parties in the air or on the ground. Communication between the remote pilot and air observers must allow sufficient time to manoeuvre the unmanned aircraft to avoid collision with manned aircraft, in accordance with UAS.SPEC.060(3)(b).

Tactical mitigation provisions require that the UAS design ensures the time between a command given by the remote pilot and the execution of that command by the unmanned aircraft does not exceed five seconds. Where electronic means assist the remote pilot or air observers in awareness of potential airspace intruders, information such as position, speed, altitude, and track must be provided with latency and update rates that support decision criteria.

Containment requirements aim to ensure safe recovery from technical issues involving the UAS or supporting external systems. There must be no probable failure of the UAS or supporting systems that would lead to operation outside the operational volume, and it must be reasonably expected that fatalities will not occur due to any probable failure. The vertical extension of the operational volume is defined as 150 metres above the surface, or another reference altitude defined by the Member State. The term ‘probable’ is clarified as meaning anticipated to occur one or more times during the entire system or operational life of an item.

Enhanced containment conditions apply when the adjacent area includes assemblies of people or when adjacent airspace is classified as ARC-d. In such cases, the UAS should be designed to standards considered adequate by the competent authority or comply with acceptable means of compliance. This includes limiting the probability of the unmanned aircraft leaving the operational volume to less than 10^-4 per flight hour and ensuring that no single failure of the UAS or supporting systems leads to operation outside the ground risk buffer. Software and airborne electronic hardware whose development errors could directly lead to operation outside the ground risk buffer must be developed according to industry standards or methodologies recognised as adequate by EASA. Notes clarify the definition of ‘failure’ and explain that some mechanical failures may be excluded if designed according to aviation best practices, and that the additional safety conditions cover both integrity and assurance levels.

Remote identification requirements state that the UAS must have a unique serial number compliant with ANSI/CTA-2063-A-2019 and be equipped with a remote identification system in accordance with Articles 40(4) and 40(5) of Regulation (EU) 2019/945. Lighting requirements specify that if the UAS is operated at night, it must be equipped with at least one green flashing light in accordance with UAS.SPEC.050(1)(l)(i). Throughout the conditions, the integrity and proof expectations commonly require references to relevant chapters or sections of the operations manual, descriptions of how conditions are met, or formal declarations of compliance, with ‘n/a’ indicated where conditions do not apply.
chunk_summary: The content defines the full set of technical, operational, and containment conditions for PDRA-G01 UAS operations. It covers monitoring capabilities, human–machine interface quality, command-and-control link robustness, tactical mitigation performance, containment and enhanced containment criteria, and regulatory equipment requirements. Compliance is generally demonstrated through self-declaration, supported descriptions, or references to the operations manual.
